text: Check-in is a breeze if you fill out the waiver online beforehand. You can save big if you check Groupon first. Tons of fun routes for a smaller sized gym. Some of the routes were much taller than I am used to.The grading seems to be pretty standard here.

I love it. It's close to where I live. I love to go here anytime I can. Seeing all the athletic people, challenging myself, and having fun. It's true, that there's not as many beginner rock walls as there was before. But I love going there for the saunas, the work out, slack line, and with friends. The people who work there are super awesome. You can choose to do harnessed climbing or bouldering.

One of my favorite hobbies I've developed after living in the Bay Area! I have friends who are avid climbers and had convinced me to come try. As for bouldering gyms go, Bridges is amazing!They reset routes every week, so you never run out of problems to attempt. The problem designations (V1, V2, etc) are pretty on-point as for the difficulty of the sets. As someone who has just graduated to V2 problem sets, I know I will be coming back to Bridges to continue leveling up.The professionals are knowledgeable and helpful and the facilities are well-maintained. There's a weight room and treadmills upstairs, and the bathrooms are always clean and well-stocked (not to mention the sauna!!).Cost-wise, Bridges is pretty typical of climbing gyms and offers discounts for college students and commuters across a bridge. They often have Groupon deals, and if you're new, you can try it for free using a member's bottomless new climber passes! Heads up, it also costs $5 to rent both a chalk bag and shoes.

If you see my profile pic, you'll realize I climb religiously. And it all started at this gym. I've checked out all the gyms in the bay. But none of them make you feel at home...unless your at BridgesThe staff is incredible, really friendly fun group.The showers are always cleanThe towels are soft towelsBest soap and conditioner I've ever used The routs are fun and creative Slack lining is a fantastic pass timeGreat classes for experienced instructors Gym Is small but well put togetherJust like homeIf it's your first time climbing.A:stretch your fingers and warm those puppiesB: when walking around the mats look above you and around you, those holds can slip and people can go flying.C: It's a good practice to spot your friend in the wall, making sure nobody walks under him or herE. If you get stuck on a problem it's ok to ask for help. F. Have fun, meet people, be safe!

Came around here the other day with a friend because my gf and I decided that we wanted to get into bouldering a bit more, and also because we have a friend who comes to climb regularly. What's pretty cool is that if it's your first time at Bridges, you can go in, free of charge (but I believe you have to have a member take you in), and it doesn't even take up the member's guest pass. Another thing that I found interesting is that once you climb to the top of a wall, you can climb over the wall where they have a platform for you to walk to a "ladder" to take you down; this is something I have not seen before at other rock climbing locations. Additionally, there are also some standard gym equipment for you to use, like many other rock climbing gyms I've been to. The gym itself is not huge, but is sizeable enough to not feel crowded with other climbers in the gym.One thing to note is that the shoes for rental are in women's sizes, so if you're a dude, order one size up!Having been at both Ironworks and Bridges now, I think I'm a pretty big fan of Bridges, just because of the sheer amount of wallspace for bouldering. Hopefully, we get into climbing more, so that we can come here more often :)

I joined Bridges during their summer special this past June. I am so happy I joined! The staff is so friendly and I especially love the spin and pilates classes. I'm still working up the courage to try climbing, but I know I'll give it a go sometime soon. I really appreciate how friendly the instructors are and the weight room area!

This has been my home gym for the past 3 years, and I could not love it more! It may not have all the bells and whistles of a Planet Granite or Touchstone gym, but it makes up for it with a tightly knit but extremely welcoming community (and of course some righteous slacklining).Just to be clear - Bridges is a bouldering gym. They do have some toproping in the back, but this is more for kids' birthday parties than anything.The reason that the routesetting is so awesome here is that they reset at least one wall every Tuesday, so you never run out of new problems! Each wall stays up for about a month so you have ample time to work on any given problem. Plenty of slab, overhangs at varying degrees, and a pretty decent-sized cave considering the size of the gym. They do tend to grade a little easier, but I think they're addressing this issue by allowing climbers to grade a problem themselves during the first week that is up, then putting up the official grade based on consensus. Pretty cool system!This gym is very friendly to beginners. For starters, there's a 3-day pass for ~$30 on Groupon! They also have an introductory class that seems very helpful from what I've overheard during my sessions. Additionally, climbers here are super-helpful if you're struggling with the beta, and not condescending at all. That's what I love about climbing... even though it's an individual sport, there's no sense of competition between climbers; we're all just trying to get up that rock!As far as membership goes, Bridges is the most budget-friendly option. For those of you who commute across a bridge (waddup Vallejo), annual membership is only $360, which is a steal! They also have semester memberships available for students.Their other workout areas are pretty nice. I like that there are always slacklines up. The weightlifting section is much-improved since they added that huge power rack. Plenty of hangboards that you can swap out too! There are several treadmills and rowing machines upstairs for those of you who actually like cardio :PLockers and bathrooms are decent. Sauna room is nice. Towels available at the front desk!Parking is just ok. They have their own lot, but it's small and cramped. The gym is right across from the super-busy 99 Ranch plaza, but I can usually find residential parking within a few blocks.

Just took my seven year-old daughter and her friend for their first climbing lesson. Benny, the instructor, made it so enjoyable: the girls had a blast, learned a lot, and grew more confident and capable over the course of the hour. By the end, they were sending their chosen routes with ease and sporting big, proud grins. Snail fist-bump FTW, Benny, thank you again!
A good place to workout. You really have different options to choose from and the staff is great. Highly reccomended.

Honestly, I'm not sure how to rate a rock gym. I had a great time here with my friends. We climbed rocks, strategized our climbs, forced each other to try hard levels, held up one another as we climbed on the upside-down wall, took fun pictures, and exhausted ourselves through and through.The staff was courteous and helpful. I only wish I knew about the Groupon deal before we each paid over $20 for single-day passes, but I'll be sure to use it next time!

TL;DR AWESOME ROCK CLIMBING WALLS + SLACK LINE!!PLUSES:+ SLACK LINING!!+ Got hooked by the Groupon ($25 for 3 passes, what a deal!)+ Hours basically all day for a regular functioning human + Affordable membership prices+ Right next to 99 Ranch+ Other classes + equipment in the gym + Friendly & helpful staff+ Shoutout to Andrew and Clara who helped my friend sign up for the SUMMER DEAL $130 for 3 months!DELTAS:- NONE

This place used to be an excellent place for beginners and everyone however, they have reduced the number of routes to about 1/3 over what it had been several years ago. So it's far less interesting and challenging.

There are very few independent gyms in metropolitan areas left. This is one of them and it remains competitive in an area with lots of competition. I would highly recommend checking them out! (Also they have my favorite competitions)

Climbing gym geared more towards straight bouldering. It's got a nice set up and all routes are marked. If it had more easy routes, I'd give them 5 stars. Everyone always crowds the easy routes and no one on the hard routes. Big imbalance. I would add 3 more easy routes.It's also got a decent slack line area.Has a Sauna :)Great yoga classes.  The yoga instructors have all been fabulous and it's in a nice quiet space. Yoga gets 5 stars for sure.Overall, a great climbing gym.

Having traveled around to visit rock climbing gyms I was excited to come back to Cali and try some of the gyms out here. I love seeing the different styles of the setters and climbing their routes. The walls here are tall!! Definitely takes some getting used to from what I see at my home gyms. Made finishing some problems a little hard because although I rock climb, I am afraid of heights. I think all it takes is a couple good falls from close to the top to improve my confidence a little. On the side of the rocks is an area for slack lining. My home gym only has one slack line. It was very cool seeing slack lines with different lengths, tightness, and hight. Much easy to get into slack lining here and a bit easier to progress as a beginner. Very cool aspect I would love my gym to take on is the peer rating for the routes. After completing a route a person can vote on the difficulty they feel the route is and how much they like the route. Very Cool!!    There is also a good sized weight gym here. So when you're not climbing you can lift weights! This would be huge for me seeing that I currently have a gym membership and a rock climbing gym membership.   The bathroom are big and clean. There are lockers that one can lock if they feel they should.    All in all I loved my experience here and I will come back the next time I'm in the area!

First time experience, I would say don't have extremely high expectations about the greeting process. It's a little corner lot just North of Pacific East Mall. In fact you can go through the parking lot and out the side/back and see the gym from that angle much better.I walked in and you have to walk through a gym area with no representatives to even get to the front desk. At the front desk there were 3-4 guys all in the middle of conversation and so being acknowledged took a bit longer than it should have. I felt like more of a burden then a welcomed new potential longtime client. I was instructed to fill out their waiver form, which is what I arrived early for with a pen ready. No pen required it's all electronic and they are set up pretty high so if you were on the shorter side you might have some problems. They do NOT have paper versions of this waiver. Also once you submit you do not get a copy of the waiver, even if you ask for one. I think that's pretty crappy in this day and age why would you not offer a copy of a legal document to the person completing it if they asked.  Not okay!Needless to say no return visits for me.

Dope spot to boulder and gym at. Membership won't completely break the bank like other rock gyms. They recently added a whole bunch of workout equipment making the place even more versatile. Slack lines and a cave is included. You can rent your climbing shoes/ chalk there or bring your own shoes and chalk. They have a small parking lot, but you can also park by the pacific east mall parking lot too. Staff is friendly! Highly recommend checking this place out!

Great experience climbing here for the summer. I wish the membership included shoe rental, it was a hassel paying for rental every day that I wished to climb (an extra $5 a day).Nevertheless this is an excellent gym, great for kids and skilled climbers a like. Also, I would suggest that you go super early as few people are climbing, lifting, or running from 6-7.

Went to the gym for the first time after I bought the Groupon online . After reading the Yelp reviews I had a clear expectation of being greeted by stinky shoes.The check in process was pretty seamless and we were given a laminated instructional sheet with all the rules and basics of bouldering. It was a little crowded mid morning but everyone was pretty good about sharing the space.The biggest star of the gym was no doubt Patrick ! He was so chill and awesome! He took the time to show us the right way to "fall" and highlighted little tips for beginners . Mid way he came back to ask us how we were doing! He even took the initiative to teach us how to slack line! He was so encouraging and knowledgeable! His presence definitely made the entire experience worth it! We will be coming back here, no questions about it! Whoever's his boss should totally give him a raise !

The only place I've ever gone bouldering, so sorry don't have anything to compare it to. My most recent experience was the after hour event on a sunday night. As an organization, we had the whole place to ourselves after hours. It was great because the workers were still there talking to us and helping us out when we needed it. Because the group had a LOT of beginners, it was good because they felt comfortable enough to just go for it and try. Also, for those that were already here, there were some good number of trails that were challenging enough. When people got tired of bouldering, they were able to play and try the slack lines which was great. All in all, great experience and props to the staff!

Went to Bridges Rock Gym for the first time a couple days ago and I was pretty bummed that I never, in my four years at Cal, took the chance to come to Bridges. It's so CLOSE to everything and located RIGHT next to 99 ranch.When you get to the location, try to park on the street or at the plaza where the 99 ranch is. The parking location is pretty small, and so you probably won't be able to find a spot. The hours can vary and so make sure to check when Bridges is open.My friends and our club had a special reservation (yes they have this!) and so we got access to the after hours at Bridges. Apparently, thats when all the workers come out and play and show off their skills. Even if we did pay for everything, passes are cheap and so are equipment.The cool thing about Bridges is that it's a GYM! There are treadmills, weights, and even a locker room. But anyway, the bouldering area is amazing. I never went before, and I definitely had a workout climbing up some of the walls. Note that "V #" stands for the difficulty. Apparently it can take 2 months to get to V2 and forever to get to higher levels like V9. The service was probably the best part. It might have been after hours, but the guys who ran the place were super chill. They gave pointers, climbed along with us, and showed us around until we left.Overall, had an amazing time at Bridges. I'll definitely keep coming back to boulder more.Have fun and prosper,

I've been getting out of my comfort zone and mixing it up with new physical activities. I found a Groupon deal for a 1 day pass, which included my shoe rental. I will say that the shoe rentals were smelly, so if you're serious about climbing, invest in a pair of climbing shoes.Since I'm new to climbing they gave me a form to read over which included rules and safety instructions for both climbing and slacklining. I didn't grab the name of the two men working the day I was there, but they were both extremely knowledgeable and helpful. One guy explained the routes to us and went over the proper falling technique.  I personally need to do some more strength training, so I found it to be a bit challenging even on the easy route. We also checked out the slack line section during our visit and had so much fun! I've seen people doing this in parks before, but didn't know what it was called. I love a good challenge and I plan on returning!

I was a member here for 5 years and had an overall positive experience and I was very hesitant when I finally ended my membership.My positives are as follows* Very friendly staff who learn your name.* Laid back patrons. Very welcoming environment.*Great classes with cool instructors. I love the review of Doug's spin class. That person is right on.*Always changing their routes. Great levels of difficulty. *Staff is kid friendly. In the summer they have a good summer camp and the routes are good for 5-15 year olds.*Towel service with really good towels.  I think they get them from bed bath and beyond. *Weight area was never too busy. Could crash the "X-fit room" when X-fit wasn't there.The only reason I gave them 4 out of 5 and ended up leaving was the cardio equipment. The gym really is a bouldering gym that has classes and a only limited assortment of cardio equipment. Because of this, there was a lot a wear and tear on the equipment (4 treadmills, 4 ellipticals, 3 lifecycles). The treadmills seem to break down at an alarming rate and 1 of the lifecycles seemed to be KOed for a long time. So I often couldn't do the workout I was supposed to because of broken equipment.  Note, this may have changed since they kept saying they would expand the cardio area.

I almost don't want to write this review and spoil this little gem secret...Been going to spin classes with Doug for quite some time and let me just say he's the best. I am thoroughly exhausted after each class.  He's a really cool and upbeat dude and he really pushes you. I use this as cross training for my marathon and I could not have picked a better choice. I think I'm in the best shape I've ever been and can definitely thank him.The rock climbing facilities are good and I love the fact that towel service is offered. Great view watching the climbers from the treadmill.This place is awesome

I recommend this gym for everyone, the staff is always friendly and happy to work there. Fun place to rock Climb, plus all kinds of other classes to take. My favorite was kickboxing with the instructor Vincent and had fun lifting weights !!

If you like bouldering this is an amazing place to go.  The gym is huge and its all bouldering with the exception of a section for slackline.  So many problems to try and not enough time.  The route setting was unique and challenging.  I definitely left with some in mind that I still wanted to figure out.  We just had one evening there with some friends while we were in town but wish we had more time.  The gym is nice and open with a LOT of problems to try.  Routes are now done with the pieces matching the color which I like, makes the walls look cleaner then having tape everywhere.  If I am in town again I would definitely come back.  If you have never rock climbed this is also a great opportunity to try it out and there are lots of levels of difficulty to try out.

First time rock climbing and it was such a fun experience! The front desk was super nice, the guy who helped me was super smiley! Since it was my first time there, I had to sign a waiver on the iPad. As soon as I finished, I was able to get my shoes right away. I used my Groupon deal, which included the shoe rental and chalk. Although it was a bit crowded, everyone was really nice. My only complaint were the shoes. They smelled soooooo bad and they were kind of damp? It was disgusting. I would definitely return. I would bring my own shoes next time :)

If I didn't live in sf, I would switch from touchstone to this gym. Let me get the not so goods out of the way first. No top roping, less bouldering than dogpatch... That's it? Now the goods.. Of which there are many.The bouldering is great here, especially for those who are newer. I brought friends who were first timers and the were able to climb some of the v3, v4 routes since it was more strength focused. However there is still lots of technical paths and a full technique wall for those more serious. Cave is really fun and I could spend hours there. Good range of difficulty so all types can enjoy. Open slack lining and free classes every Saturday! Easy enough perk to take advantage of if you want to try it out. Full gym, yoga classes, sauna. This place really has it all. Even if you were just looking for a gym membership with occasional climbing, this would be a great deal. The staff are very friendly and helpful too! Easy to talk to and there to help whenever you need something. If you're just looking to try out climbing, this is a great place to start. Pick up the groupon for an even better deal!

I have been wanting to explore rock climbing for a while and the Intro to Bouldering class with Jesse sealed the deal.  He was very encouraging, enthusiastic, and read us and our ability level really well.  My partner and I signed up under a couple's membership and are enjoying the benefits already.  The slack lines and gym are great for breaks from bouldering.  FYI, this is a bouldering gym.

They have a cheap Groupon pass $26 for three visits, much cheaper than most rock gyms' single day pass, which is around $25. The downside is that it's usually pretty crowded. But nice thing is that people there are super friendly and staff are very chill too. I hope they can clean their rocks more often so that they're not often smoothened by the extra chalk on them. ;)

Bridges is a great little gym! Given the quality and diversity of their services, and the low cost of membership, they're way more cost-effective than Touchstone. They offer a standard set of gym equipment, a decent weight room, access to a sauna, slacklines, and fitness classes for members at no additional cost. Additionally, Sonja offers awesome sports massages and has made a big difference in my recovery from a back injury.The only annoying things are that it can get very crowded, it tends to attract some obnoxious children and teens who disrupt people's workouts, and they rope off much of the climbing walls for several days surrounding bouldering competitions. Honestly, the price and atmosphere are right, so those issues don't affect my opinion of the gym.

Went for a massage with Justin, who seems like he might be kind of new at the gym. So here's my review!Setting up the massage, I called in to the number listed on their website, and eventually a massage person called back. She had me go online and fill out their waiver form, then call into the main office to help me redeem my Groupon in time (it was expiring soon). She gave me a convenient time slot for the massage, within a half a week.Arriving at the gym for the massage, I came about 10 minutes early, which was good, because they had me fill out another form (besides the waiver) about my health history, sore muscles, etc. Then I was to bring the form to meet my massage practitioner, Justin. I recalled from another Yelp review that it was kind of a bummer to wait in a rock climbing gym, as opposed to in a day spa...but I didn't have to wait at all, was greeted immediately upon entering the "massage corner," even though I was still a tad early.Justin's massage started with a couple of minutes of touch without any oil--I was reminded of the feeling of rubber, and was wondering if a sports-style massage doesn't use oil. But then, with oil, he massage my back, concentrating on my lower back. I won't lie, it was a little painful, but I decided to go with it. Glad I did, because the massage seems to have opened up some kind of new energy for me. I found myself thinking about a professional problem that's been plaguing me for a few weeks, and I came up with a solution. Do  you think massage brings oxygen to the brain? The rest of the massage felt great--no pain, even around my knees that had been troubling me. I don't know much about what a sports massage would be like--I've mostly gone to day spas out of town while on vacation--but the style of this massage wasn't radically different than the others I've had.The "massage corner" was darkly lit, no audible noise from the gym right outside, and In the background played some great piano music (not New Age, thank goodness, more like Jazz/ Classical/ Improv).  Nice paintings!Used the restroom while I was there, it had a sauna and showers. I didn't ask specifically whether massage clients could use them, but it looked like a clever person might easily get away with it :-)

I have been coming here quite often since they have an amazing Groupon only $41 for 5 day passes!This gym is located next to an Asian plaza, since the parking lot is kind of small you could park in the plaza.  This is a bouldering gym, they have a top roping section but the walls are only 18 ft tall.  This gym has the tallest bouldering wall in America 18.5 feet, it is highly suggested that you do not climb this wall until you can climb the lower walls since falling from the 18.5 ft.. wall is dangerous. There are many different routes here from VB - V10 level. The majority of the routes are more strength - based, but they do have some technique based routes which I personally find a lot funner to do. They also have a cave which is where the more advanced climbers usually climb, unfortunately I do not have the arms of a spider monkey so I cannot climb the cave yet. This gym gets really crowded on friday nights.. there were at least over 100 people which was kind of unsafe since people were jumping every where and not watching where they landed. I love this place because they have many different routes all of different levels! You should come here if you want to get better at bouldering / work on your technique, the day pass is only $10 before 3, and $12 after 3 pm!!!! So even without the groupon it is still worth it to come and try at least once !

I was a little hesitant about coming here and trying bouldering for the first time. I just didn't see the appeal! And after my experience, I can't say it's my new favorite activity but this gym is pretty great. First of all, the staff is super nice and really helpful in explaining everything from prices (student night!) to how the heck to get started on those walls. Second, I was pretty intimidated especially because I went on a Friday evening and it was soooo crowded, but I quickly realized people there were friendly and also don't give a sh*t about how poorly I'm climbing. I gave it a good number of tries but I could never get to the very top so I went upstairs and ran a mile on the treadmill to feel better about myself. Then I mastered the purple slack line and it was a good night. Affordable prices with a variety of activities. Come here with friends even if not everyone is into bouldering.
The place is pretty small and rather crowded. Parking felt impossible. But the perks are that staff is really friendly and we had a ton of fun.

I go bouldering here occasionally. It gets pretty crowded sometimes, but I like that there are a lot of different walls available. They also have tight ropes that you can play around on if you want a break from rock climbing.The staff is always super friendly and helpful. Sometimes if they see you having trouble with a route, they come over and give you tips.The locker room/bathrooms are really clean. I'm kind of OCD, and I really like this place overall. Sometimes gyms smell, but this place does not.

I am a total beginner!!! I got a groupon deal for this place and it was WORTH IT!!! It makes me want to get an actual membership! Too bad I live an hour away. This place is VERY busy. A lot of kids come here and they aren't rowdy so it make the experience a whole like more pleasant for a beginner like me. There are also a lot of hardcore people and if you're a beginner as well, don't be intimidated! There are a ton of beginners too!!! I wish there was like a pamphlet of how they do things here. They have color coded tape on rocks and a letter and number to show where to start. I wouldn't have known that if my bf told me. Pretty much if you're a beginner, find a starting point that has a letter, then a "B." After you get the hang of all the "B" ones, work way way from 0-7. I'm not sure if there is more than 7. They also have a gym, kickboxing lessons and yoga.The bathroom is SO CLEAN!!! It has lockers, a SAUNA, shower, scale and lotion (for your tired hands). The staff is very friendly and helpful. Everything about this place makes me want to come back, and I most definitely will!!!

This gym is awesome. So worth the membership... even when I take months off ;) Seriously,1) bouldering: They change routes every week and they range from starter level to pro with some routes set to work on techniques. They also host competitions.2) Yoga: Awesome, talented instructors3) Spin: again awesome, but I'm biased.4) Weight room and other fitness/ dance classes: Love the weight room, haven't been to the dance or fitness classes, but they look fun!4) Kickboxing and Boxing classes: The main reason I go. Such a great work out and the instructors are super nice, not intimidating but very knowledgeable and love teaching. Seriously, Kickboxing and Boxing classes are the bomb-diggity (I know no one says that anymore but I'm bringing it back.)extras: showers, saunas, free towel service, massage therapy, and it isn't part of a corporate group. Front desk staff are helpful and fun.Finally, it's next door to a Asian Mall/Market which gives you some good options for post-workout grub.Check it out.

Bouldering, top rope, slacklining, and a gym all in one for a really good price? This is it, people. The employees are all nice and friendly, the crash pads are the best, and it doesn't get any better than this for beginner boulderers. I go here mainly for the bouldering wall, which occupies like 75% of the gym. And, I'm afraid of heights, but you get to top out on almost every side of the walls, and they have varying lengths and overhangs, as well as difficulties. Ok, it's by far the best climbing gym I've been to, and I had a terrible ankle sprain from climbing years ago, but Bridges helped me regain some confidence back. :)Bridges is such a chill place for even hang outs, so if you're looking for a great neighborhood gym, this place will meet your needs! Not to mention, they have yoga and other classes, too.

This place is pretty cool!Online waivers, which makes it easy for kids to get parents' approval and come climb. $12.50 for the day of climbing or so, not including shoe rentals (which I imagine aren't strictly necessary if you have converse or sneakers). Good number of different walls, from easier to more challenging, each with appropriate route markings. While we were there there were a couple little girls as well as a good number of teenage/older boys, i.e. pretty varied in age but all still kids or young adults (guess that's the population rock climbing most appeals to ^^).The one downside: basically no harnesses. Which really limits you since you're at risk if you slip, and I imagine you can really hurt yourself if you fall from the top of one of the walls.

Tips:$6 for a one day pass for students on Friday evenings.$3 for shoe rental.This is bouldering, no harness needed!------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------This was my very first time experiencing rock climbing in general and I didn't realize that there was a difference between bouldering and rock climbing with a harness. VB and V0 are the easiest level paths and those were the ones that I was tackling. Rock climbing is surprisingly such a good workout! I can't believe that I never experienced it before, but my arms and legs were sore after climbing for so long.Bridges is a great place to experience rock climbing without a harness and for the student price of $6 I'd definitely go again!

The first time I went here was with a friend. We came here for rock climbing. They offer a very, very limited space for rock climbing. According to the staff, they weren't licensed in rock climbing. Therefore they had to test us whether is we knew how to belay in order to give us access to rock climbing. In the end, after questions of rock climbing commands and how to strap the harness on properly, the staff refused to allow us access to rock climbing. If we signed waivers that declared that we won't sue them for injuries, why would if matter it we knew the commands at all, especially if we knew how to wear the harness properly and also know how to belay? Very disappointed in this place. I would give it a -1, if possible.

Staff is friendly and accepting to new members. Did their Friday deal for climbing. Everyone is supportive and friendly. Lots of room to try out different levels. Spotless bathrooms. Didn't see a grain of chalk in there.

This place was awesome. The staff was nice and helpful. I bought this through a Groupon and it included a shoe rental and all day pass which was really awesome. It is a little intimidating because there aren't any harnesses for most of the climbing. The floor however is thickly padded and people who did fall seemed to jump back up without any trouble.There were a lot of people since I did go around 8PM. Definitely recommend this place!
Very friendly and helpful staff and always have a good time exercising there. Generally other customers are also very chill and fun.

If you have ever wanted to go bouldering, this is the place to be.  The staff is really knowledgeable and friendly.  The boulders range from easy to very challenging, and there are thick mats everywhere so you don't have to worry that if you fall you'll break your back.Just to clarify, bouldering is the type of rock climbing with no harnesses.  I think I must have been a monkey in my past life because I was scaling those walls like it was what I was born to do. That being said, it's still scary, because you have no harness.  But sometimes, it's the fear of falling to your death that really propels you to keep holding on until you reach the top.  For some reason, I kept thinking about Bruce Wayne in the 3rd Batman movie.

I've been here with a small group of 3, a medium group of 10, and a large group of 20. Whatever the group size, this place rocks! (Pun intended). I would recommend coming in the afternoon if you're coming with a big group.The problems (routes) are pretty varied and fun. In addition to bouldering, there are ropes and rings off to the side that are a lot of fun, even if you are like me and have no idea what you're doing with those things. I wish the place was a little bigger, and the workout gym could be better (though I have particularly high standards for gyms). Overall, though, there is still plenty to keep me occupied for easily 3 hours every time I come. For comparison, I've also been to Planet Granite in south bay, as well as a few other rock gyms.The staff were chill. They gave tips, but only if you wanted them. And when I just wanted to fool around (i.e. attempt to balance on the ropes, or try to do a flip on the bouncy floor), I never felt judged. In fact, I felt pretty much at ease to just try whatever I wanted, as long as I wouldn't put other people at harm.Most of the time I had a car, but once I took BART and walked to get here, and it wasn't too bad of a walk.Caveat: Bouldering is pretty different than climbing. So if you're expecting to be harnessed up and climbing huge walls, then you will be disappointed. But I personally have done a decent amount of both, and I find bouldering to be much more fun.Protip: If you're new to climbing, expect your hands to turn red and your muscles to be sore!

I was introduced to this place by my boyfriend. I come with him once a month with his membership guest pass. Time goes by so fast when you are having fun burning calories, toning your body, and sweating! We usually go on weekend mornings. Quiet and no judgements! They offer Groupon deals once awhile. Look for them!

My friend got a membership to this place and dragged me out here.  It was the best investment I made in a gym membership.  They have climbing walls for bouldering, some free weights, some exercise machines, and they hold classes such as yoga, zumba and kick boxing.  The change the routes pretty often to keep it interesting.  The Ranch 99 plaza is conveniently located next door for that post workout meal or run to the grocery store.  It is too bad that I am moving down south to LA, otherwise I would continue to come here.

Thank goodness for my friend introducing me to this awesome activity. At my first visit, I was blown away by the rock climbing walls as it looked challenging and fun. It was my first time bouldering. The staff were super friendly and did not give off the vibe of "douche." As I went with a pro friend of mine, he taught me the basics and what the colors and numbers meant. Price for an all day is about $30 including shoes and chalk. I'm not sure if it includes the other amenities (gym, yoga, massage). However, buy the groupon deal for you save hella money and it does include amenities. An hour away from me will not stop me from coming here :) I really wish they had one closer to me. In a heart beat, I'll switch my Crunch membership to here.

Amazing place, I have been a member for two years, but it would be even more amazing if they would offer a Capoeira class there!!!  I take Capoeira class at Tatami Multi-Arts and it is moving to another location in July 2015, so the clientele from its martial arts classes, especially Capoeria, would be likely to take classes at Bridges, if they were to offer.  My suggestion is to approach the instructor currently teaching Capoeira there about teaching at Bridges, if they decline, perhaps contacting a Capoeira studio in the area would be a great idea.

Came here with a huge group (20 people) on a Saturday afternoon, but they were pretty empty, and we all had room to climb! We had bought the Yelp deals, so our passes included shoe rentals and chalk. I've been here a couple of times, but I've never been rock climbing with a harness before, so I don't know whether there's a big difference between rock climbing and bouldering, but I think it's pretty easy to pick up! It's requires quite a bit of exertion, and you'll probably be sore the next day, but it's lots of fun, and you definitely get a sense of achievement from being able to climb to the top!The staff were all super friendly, and the bathroom/locker room facilities were really nice! Definitely worth coming back!

Granted, this is the first and only rock gym I've ever been to, but I've seen pictures of other rock gyms and they don't seem nearly as good. Bridges was my first introduction to bouldering, something I seriously thought I'd never get really into. But Bridges changed my mind. The price is pretty great ($40 something a month for students and the "couples" deal) and the community is fantastic. There is also such a great variety of routes, and a turnover that is, in my opinion, perfect for those who come 2-3 times a week. But let me get back to the community. The regulars that come to Bridges are amazing people - both in bouldering talent and also amiability. Everyone is so open to helping each other out and solving problems together, it's the perfect atmosphere for a hobby you turn to after a long day of work or class. Also the staff here are pretty great, they're very friendly and you can chill with them out on the rocks too.

I've come here a few times with groups of 20 to just 2 and had a pretty good experience every time. It can get pretty crowded on popular times like Friday nights (the Cal climbing team goes here then), but people here are always friendly, helpful, and nice in general in addition to the great staff. The gym is mostly for bouldering although there is a wall with harnesses and there are also some good slacklines on the side as well. There is a good range and good number of easy to challenging routes and they change the walls ever week or so I believe to keep me challenged. There is also a good gym on the side with weights and workout machines, a room for fitness classes, and a good, clean bathroom with a sauna, so it's a great gym in addition to a bouldering gym. If you do rent their shoes, the shoes can be a bit smelly (but they do lysol them down!) so make sure to wear socks! I eventually bought my own pair because not wearing socks allows your foot to grip the rock better.

No crowds! I used to live in Sausalito, and Planet Granite was the closest climbing gym. There would always be so many people there, and I constantly felt like I was being watched and judged - which made me even more nervous as I usually boulder outdoors and don't have as much experience bouldering indoors. At Bridges Rocky Gym, I feel completely at ease and confident. Plus I love the slacklines that are always ready! I can take my shoes off and jump onto the slack lines when my arms need a break from bouldering! The bathroom is really nice and clean, as well as the sauna and shower room. Staff is friendly, along with the other folks who visit the gym.
Real cool experience! Great workout! A few days of bouldering and you'll be a fit, trim, lean mean dancing machine! Go for it! Have the bucks tho! Used a groupon courtesy of a friend.

I got a month membership here when I came to visit for a couple weeks, and I primarily wanted to do yoga and Spinning classes, not rock climbing which seems to be what most people come here for.The group fitness classes are a relatively new addition to the gym's programs, especially Spinning. There were only a handful of people in the Spinning classes (and I actually was the ONLY person taking a Spinning class one morning). The Spinning classes take place in the small group fitness studio, and they drag a few bikes in for each class (and then take them away after class). The only thing that bothered me about this is the fact that the bikes were sitting on the soft mats, which meant the bikes moved slightly each time my weight shifted side to side during pedaling.The yoga classes take place in a tin shed (literally) next to the main building of the gym, but the interior of the shed is actually quite nice. Clean, smooth hardwood floors, nicely painted walls, good insulation (which was essential since I was there during winter), and nice yoga props. Very cozy.I got to do some rock climbing one day while I was there, and it was a lot of fun. Most of the routes are free climbing, but there is one wall where you can belay with buddy. It had been over 10 years since I had last done any rock climbing, so it was an interesting experience trying to climb again, but it was fun! You can rent shoes if needed, and also chalk if you like.There is a weight room with weight machines (if that's your kind of thing), and also a few treadmills upstairs for some cardio.Very nice and very helpful staff. Instructors for the Spinning and yoga classes are great.When I go back to CA to visit, I'm pretty sure I will come back here for my yoga, Spinning, and even try some more climbing, and maybe try some of the other group fitness classes they offer (tai chi, group strength, etc.).

Michael Hoffman is a great massage therapist.  Too bad the rock climbing center smells like feet and over run by children during their day camp rock climbing activities.  It's not relaxing being surrounded by lots of little kids.  Their waiting area is shabby and not exactly comfortable.  This is a great place for rock climbing but not a great spa experience for a massage.  Again, that is not the fault of the massage therapist.  He's wonderful.

To start off my return to the Review World!I'll review one of my favorite to-go pastimes when I'm looking to level up physically and spiritually Rock ClimbingThough this doesn't beat rock climbing on actual mountains, it is a good alternative if you are a college student in the bay area. There is a good variety of different levels which actually separate the clientele very well in the sense that not everyone is advanced, beginner, or intermediate. You will always have a place to climb. The safety is also secure as I have taken some huge multi story bumps and not even got hurtPlus the kicker, It's only 6 dollars on friday if you have a student ID

Updating my review because I ended up getting the semester deal! Also writing one because I just had my last climbing sesh at Bridges 3 weeks ago and I really, really miss it.I seriously love this place so much. This was my last semester at Berkeley and this is one of the places I'll miss the most about the East Bay. This gym is so awesome and Bridges got me obsessed with climbing!The routes are changed frequently so you'll never get bored. The staff members are SO friendly and welcoming. I just got a one month membership via Groupon to Planet Granite in the South Bay and it has a completely different vibe than Bridges. It's MUCH bigger and I feel like I'm constantly judged when I'm on the wall, lol. It's always really crowded and it makes me really miss Bridges. Granted, (or should I say Granite, haaahaha) Planet Granite is not just a strictly bouldering gym, but still. I miss my beloved Bridges.Waahh, will I ever find a bouldering gym like Bridges? Who knows. Please come here and get a membership, it's awesome. The price isn't bad at all compared to other climbing gyms and it has such a chill vibe.I already miss it.
I got into Bouldering because of this gym.On weekdays, it's $10 for a day pass.People are friendly and it's never too crowded.I hope I have some time to come back here.

This review is for the Zumba class I took there. 3 stars is a stretch!  But at least I was able to burn off some holiday calories. Only because I stepped it up for myself. The instructor was boring, more like a class for seniors, seriously. Plus she kept her back to us most of the class. The room is tiny. Granted it was the Saturday after Christmas but there were a total of FOUR students, myself, two I invited and one other!  I only went there because the facility were I normaly go was closed for vacation. After class she didn't bother to greet us or encourage us to come back and I won't!  No Zumba love here!

What a great rock climbing gym! It's truly a hidden gem as it is tucked away in the corner at the end of the cul-de-sac. Parking around here isn't always so easy either, as it's either at their tiny lot or on the street.This gym is better for bouldering than rock climbing, which fits my interests more. There's a large boulder in the middle where you can climb. Also surrounding wall to top over and a small underside rock. The courses will change every once in a while, which helps keep it entertaining! Not to mention a small studio to work out in, some weight machines, slack lining, a few cardio equipment, and a sauna room. Pack all those things into a gym and you got a well rounded place.The people who work here are super nice and friendly. There's even a smoothie bar upstairs for after your workouts. The prices here compared to many other rock gyms is really reasonable. The costs also appeal more to the students as well. So you'll find a lot of Cal kids here as well as other local students.If I only lived closer to this area, I'd make this my main gym! Look out for the Groupon deal to get a punch card of 3x or 5x, which I highly recommend to start off with. It's the best deal I've seen out there. Plus having this deal will waive your initiation fee later if you decide to join.

Five stars to Vince and Thomas for their ***boxing and kickboxing*** program. The focus is on fighting technique and fighter training through no-contact partner drills and conditioning. Whether you've never worn boxing gloves or you've had years of training, Vince and Thomas are very welcoming and will work with you at your level. I can't recommend them highly enough.(The rest of the bouldering gym is pretty great too.)

This place is awesome! I have never really gone bouldering/top roping, but a friend of mine invited me to come out and climb with him. I came on a friday around 8pm for college night and it was packed. I initially had trouble finding spots to climb but people started to leave around 9pm. I am a complete newb when it comes to climbing and half expected to see some snobby ass people looking down on me, but it was the exact opposite. I felt very comfortable climbing and people even gave me pointers/helped me during my climb. I will definitely come by as often as possible.

Before visiting Bridges the other night, I had never previously tried indoor rock climbing. It has always been something I've been interested in, but I just never had the chance. A few months ago, I had a blast in my brief introduction to outdoor climbing (see review of Cragmont Park yelp.com/biz/cragmont-pa…), but from what I've heard, the indoor experience is quite different.So, with yet another SFGate deal in tow, I met up with a friend after work to check out the beginners class at Bridges. From the get go, I could tell that the atmosphere was friendly and welcoming, and even though both of us were absolute n00bs, no one seemed to think any less of us.When we walked in, we were greeted by Chris (who was also the teacher). He was very friendly, and didn't mind answering any of our asinine rookie questions. The gym itself - although not very large - is very clean, and patrons can immediately notice that the ownership takes great pride in maintaining the facilities.I'm not sure how crowded it can get on weekends or on nights when they have special events, but on this Wednesday evening, around 7 pm, it was relatively quiet, then picked up a bit around 8. It never got to the point of overcrowding with people bumping into each other. There was still plenty of room for everyone to enjoy the walls.As mentioned earlier, since I am a rookie to indoor rock climbing, I really no have a basis for comparison with other facilities, but one thing that confused me here is the labeling of the routes. They use a system that starts with B for beginner, continuing upward through a series of numbers to indicate difficulty, all preceded by the letter V. So, VB would be the absolutely easiest, followed by V1, V2, and up.However, sometimes it seemed that the ones deemed the lowest in difficulty were not such a cinch after all, and others with V4 and above were a snap. Perhaps I was doing it wrong, but I'll probably figure it out as I return to use up the remainder of my SFGate passes.As for the comparison to outdoor climbing, other than the obvious disparity in equipment involved, I must say that they aren't so different after all. They both ultimately require the same level of concentration, the same muscle groups, and similar technique. I'm not well versed enough in the "culture" of rock climbing to know if there is any rivalry between the two groups (I assume there is), but I enjoy both equally as well.The barrier of entry for indoor climbing is much less imposing, as no equipment is needed, much less instruction is required, and above all, it is much more affordable and accessible. You can pretty much take off and visit the indoor gym whenever it strikes your fancy - much like you would the normal fitness center - but the same certainly cannot be said for outdoor climbing.If you don't feel like climbing walls on certain days, there are also treadmills, slacklines, a dry sauna, and even a soon to be weight room currently in the works! With the all day pass, feel free to come in and out throughout the course of the day.Best of all, Bridges is located conveniently adjacent to Pacific East Mall, which should more than satisfy all of you Asian food aficionados out there. Don't forget to stop by J&S (yelp.com/biz/j-and-s-cof…) for some of the finest milk tea in the Bay!
Great place!!! Had a blast. Friendly people, great environment. Cannot wait to go back!

Great all around gym with such a variety of activities.  Not sure if I'll return though... But only because it doesn't suit my specific needs.  If I were looking for a gym to be a member of, then this would probably be it, for sure.  It's super close to my house, it has all the desired activities you wish every gym had included in one low packaged price! Unfortunately, I'm not that type of climber, at least not right now.  I maybe go a half dozen times a year with friends and family for specific occasions.  We prefer rope climbing and rarely explore bouldering areas.  If bouldering is your preference, then this is definitely the place for you because it has a very large variety compared to other spots in the bay area.Be warned that the parking lot is pretty small... I would say around a dozen spots or so?  We started off at 4:30pm on a Friday.  By the time 8pm rolled around, the place was PACKED (which isn't too hard to do since it's not that big of a spot to begin with).  It took a few minutes to find parking (which involved sitting in my car til someone left and pulled out).  The bouldering area itself is not very big so there are people sitting pretty much everywhere which makes it intimidating for beginners who have to find an empty "segment" to climb.  It didn't stop my visitors from having a good time but I do believe they would have enjoyed it much more if it were a little more spacious.Bottom line... We would probably go again, but only if we really didn't want to do much rope climbing.

I can tell why people like going here. This place is huge and there are just walls and walls of bouldering possibilities. Some people go free style and there are people like me who have to be linked up with a spotter. I am not much of a climber but the time I went, it was really fun to hang out with friends and just climb. There are tightropes and a small gym at the facility as well. My favorite thing was the zip-lining from the top of the wall to the floor. I am definitely not a fan of heights and it was scary to do the initial drop, but it is so fun and exhilarating! **TIPS**1) I read online that you can get a summer membership deal so I would inquire about that.2) Try zip-lining! It's a baby step for the real thing.3) Enjoy!

The routes here are still great, but I think they're hitting some speed bumps as their business grows. 1. The prices here keep fluctuating. They get you in with a good deal, then don't offer the same prices for renewal, only to say you have to pay an expensive $50 initiation fee or commit to 6-months of membership. No, I'm not annoyed. Well, maybe a little bit. 2. They ran out of locks the last couple of times I was there. 3. Sometimes they have class field trips at the gym. I'm all for supporting the kiddies, but the gym can feel overrun. All this said, I still like climbing here. Just not sure how they will cope with the growing pains. They need to figure out a consistent pricing plan that works with their business soon.

First time experience is that staff is friendly, the route setting is quality and there is a sauna.   Enjoyed the layout of the wall for the gym and the problems.  All the other climbers I spoke with in the gym seemed friendly and there was a good vibe in the gym.  Only downside is that is gets pretty busy and the gym isn't that big.

Pretty much an all bouldering gym with some slack lines to balance on.I went on a Friday and got the student discount so I was able to boulder for 4-5 hours for $10. GOOD DEAL. Similar to SLO OP in San Luis Obispo.HIGH lone boulders and top outs. Lots of fun. Mostly college kids there.

While the offerings were pretty impressive, the execution and lack of professional accountability gives major pause. I signed up for the 1-year membership during their recent NO INITIATION FEE special.  The following 3 times I visited the gym, I was sorely disappointed.  Each time I went to attend a group exercise class.  Each time the instructor did not show up.  The 1st time this happened, the front desk would not or could not articulate what the class cancellation policy was.  The 2nd time it happened, I was offered a free guest pass for my trouble.  The 3rd time it happened, I decided I'd request a refund.  I understand that they are in a transition, but this is unacceptable.   What kind of business are they running here when employees don't show up for their job?  THREE times in a row,  THREE different employees.Thanks, but no thanks.

BOULDERING! I suck at it, but it's still fun nonetheless. I like that bridges keep their gym pretty clean! Stop climbing for a bit and do a little bit of slacklining while giving your fingers a break from blisters of climbing.I bought the groupon deal for 3 visits for $24 that includes rental equipment too! AWESOME deal! Afterwards, you can just trek on over to the Pacific East Mall and grub! PS. Bridges is realllyyyy clean! I like clean climbing gyms that don't smell like feet!PSS. There is no expiration date w/ the groupon deal! AWESOME!

Nice, mostly bouldering gym.  They have a few, short top rope routes.  The setting is hit or miss - some routes are set pretty hard, others are super easy. You can top out most of the bouldering problems but watch your head.  Some of the top outs are really close to the supports for the building and the walkoffs require you to duck a lot.If you are looking for a climbing gym to have a kid's birthday party, I'd pick this one.  Much cleaner than your regular climbing gym.  They have a nice table upstairs where you have your pizza or cake without being in a cloud of chalk dust.Now that I've encouraged people to have their kid's parties here, I'd like to point out that the kids here can get super annoying for people trying to work out.  The staff tries to keep them in the top rope area, but that usually fails.  The kids are attracted to the top out bouldering like a moth to a flame.  They run around the top out area, making a ton of noise and being super annoying.  On top of that, the staff and parents are constantly yelling at the kids to stop but to no avail.For parents, keep in mind that you are in a gym.  Would you let your child loose in a 24 Hour Fitness to run around and scream and climb all over the gym equipment?  I sure hope not.  Despite the brightly colored holds and fun bouncy gym mats, this is the same thing as any other gym.  People are here to work out.  Plus, the climbers could fall at any moment, crushing your precious baby girl or boy.  So try to keep them on a short leash. Also, the top out bouldering can be super dangerous and I've seen way too many kids up there, precariously close to the edge of the boulder.  If they fall off, birthday party fun is over so keep them under control for everyone's sake.

I've been receiving massage from Sonja Gubalke, regularly, for the last few months and I so appreciate her work. I suffer from muscle tightness along my low back and, also, sore feet. Along my back, I want deep tissue massage, but on my feet , I need a lighter touch or I'll be in pain.  She can do both. She gives a great deep tissue massage, but she listens too, and is responsive to my changing needs. The quality of her work has  always been very consistent, respectful and professional. I highly recommend her.

I love this place! lots of climbing routs that change frequently, the slacklines are super fun, and there's a sauna to chill at when you're done and all of you body aches...Plus the staff is really nice and the background music is always fun.

Really nice gym.I bought the groupon which is an amazing deal, $8 per drop in for 5 day passes which include shoe rental and classes. The staff are very friendly. The workout equipment upstairs is nice and kept clean. Love the slacklines.I'm new to climbing and they have a good number of zeros and ones for beginners. It's also fun to be at a gym where you can stand on top of the rock when you get to the top.I do find that the routes are a little less interesting than the routes at iron works. There aren't as many ways to climb a given route as there are fewer holds on each route. Makes it a little less interesting.

Really fantastic bouldering gym. There is pretty much no point coming here to top rope, but if you want to try bouldering (climbing w/o harness to a height that is still safe to jump or fall and not hurt yourself) this is the place to go. It's cheap, the staff is friendly, and the routes are changed pretty frequently. Even when it's at the most crowded hours, you shouldn't have to wait too long to get on the wall.There's some machines, kettle bells, and freeweights (dumbbells not barbells) as well as a large slacklining area. They have cardio machines as well. One complaint I've heard from more experienced people is that the types of moves the routesetters favor are all "bigger moves" that favor strength over technique, but personally I can't really complain.

Came here first time for a massage. Had to fill out a liability release form (for the gym), and a typical massage intake form.The massage itself was okay. The massage room is inside the gym. Don't expect a spa like environment.

I haven't been to many rock climbing gyms besides Planet Granite and this one, but compared to Planet Granite... this one wins HANDS DOWN.I bought a groupon to Bridges Rock Gym - $24 for 3 day passes. The passes include in and outs, all rentals, all gym equipment, the sauna and all classes they offer. How freakin' generous is that??? The staff there are super helpful, personal and approachable. No intimidation here.The bathrooms are nice and clean. People can hold parties on the second floor. It's not as big as Planet Granite but this place definitely has its perks. It's also way more affordable. Student price on Friday is only $6.00!This will probably be my go-to rock climbing gym. My bff comes here very frequently and she loves it.

this place gets FIVE STARS for the kid's program, no idea how the other memberships are.my 11 year old is doing the after school climbing program. it is 2 hours, 1 or 2 days a week.  they do ropes, bouldering  & slacklining.  tons of personal attention, very low pressure.  IT'S AWESOME.  some quirky kids, but what are you gonna do, it's the Bay Area.  mad props to the staff that run the program, Austin & Emily. they are GREAT with the kids-- supportive, patient, kind & obviously love their jobs. they have a full report for parents upon pick up.

I've been here a few times and each time is super fun and such a great place to get a good work out. I usually come here on student fridays but recently they had a Yelp deal and purchased that so I can bring a few friends. I am not a fan of heights, but they have a lot of levels, that even a newbie can learn and have a fun time. The staff is friendly and informative, definitely ask questions and they are more than happy to help. I love bouldering with friends because you can encourage each other and help each other spot specific color rocks. Lockers and bathrooms are clean and they provide you with locks if you need it. Also they have weight machines towards the entrance if you want to get some more work outs in. They also have slack lines which are super fun to try out. I have horrible balance, so its always a funny sight.

I've never been to a bouldering gym before, so I was really excited!That being said, I definitely didn't expect Bridges to be so goshdarn difficult to climb. I guess it's true- rock climbing gyms are infinitely easier. Who knew I'd end up missing harnesses!What I enjoyed about Bridges was that there was a ton of things to check out. Other than the obvious reason-- bouldering-- Bridges boasts a few slackline areas (try and see how good your balance is!), a weight room, and a ping-pong room furnished with various hula hoops, jump ropes, and, um, some large fans...?My only complaint is that I wish the courses were easier to handle and less tiring! I felt that we didn't spent a significant amount of our afternoon here, so I don't know if I'd be willing to pay full price (we had a CampusCred deal). But then again, I AM a skinny Asian girl, so take my opinion with a grain of salt.

This is a great place.  Took my roommates here last night (I usually come once or twice a month with friends) and it was quite a fun time.  I usually will take climbing newbies here since at IronWorks I have to teach them how to belay and that just takes time!Pros:1.  Close to my house/BART2.  Lots of space, even when it's crowded you can find a good route3.  Very friendly atmosphere.  No judging going on here!4.  Affordable day-pass/memberships5.  Routes are well maintained, changed pretty regularly, and of all levels (VB to V10)PROTIP:  After climbing for a few hours, head on over to 99 Rance for some awesome BOBA!Cons:None come to mind...will update if I can think of any!

Great staff, clean environment, fun for the whole family . We had my sons birthday after hours 6:30~10:00 We had the place to.ourselves after the gym closed to members and the kids Got to climb, slack rope, and sing  karaoke , play Nerf dart tag. They have a Nice area for food set~up, to sit and relax for parents and the 15 kids to eat and rest. I would recommend this place to anyone who wants a rock climbing party . We will be back.

I love Bridges for a bouldering gym as well as a regular workout gym. All the employees are friendly and the members are super nice as well. There are just a great variety of boulder problems and super duty foam mats for when the harder problems aren't going your way. It's a nice overall gym because they have a couple of treadmills, stationary bikes, elipticals, free weights and a bunch of weight machines. There's also a few slacklines and even an area for newbs to learn. They have a pretty impressive list of classes they offer that's free with membership (pilates, zumba, yoga, kickboxing, etc.). There's even a sauna in the locker room. There's also an area on the second floor for working and studying that's often filled with kids for their birthday parties during the weekends. Unlike other gyms, I don't find it considerably smelly or filled with chalk. There's a huge wall that they open that helps ventilate the place. Everything's always really clean and I definitely appreciate that.

Don't be fooled - this is a bouldering gym. There are only a very small number of roped climbs set up, and at less than 2-stories high, they're marginally satisfying. The availability of several slacklines (tightrope-walking, essentially) is an unusual and cool feature, and the staffer was nice about offering tips. The range of spaces and options make this likely a fun place to rent out for a party. In addition to the extensive bouldering, there's a small weight room, cardio area, M/F locker rooms with saunas, a kitchen(!), and a lounge area complete with DVD and Playstation. They offer yoga and other fitness classes in a separate but adjacent shed.If I needed to do some training for a climb, I might come back again. My final hesitation is their liability waiver. I'm fine to acknowledge that climbing is risky (especially unroped), but I get worried when the management abdicates responsibility even in the case of staff negligence.

I've been going here for a few months now fairly regularly and  I love it. It's one of my favorite places to be right now. The staff are friendly and helpful. The membership is well worth it when you consider all you get out of it:weightsrock climbingfree classesand more that I'm forgetting.I'm taking a free climbing clinic at the moment and it's really helping me on my technique (Sue is awesome!). I've mostly stuck to the lower level of difficulty, but after one class I am able to jump another level or two up.

I've been to several rock gyms (through out SoCal and in Europe) and this place was decent. I think it is a great place for locals and especially college students to spend some quality workout time at. The gym is relatively small, but there are many different climbs to check out. There is a gym floor and an upstairs floor with cardio equipment. There are also free classes if you are a member which include yoga, slacking, and many more. The community at this gym seemed very friendly and supportive and the staff at the front desk were friendly as well. I came to redeem a Groupon deal, which made my visit super cheap! I however did not give this gym the highest review because of the size, and the very unpleasant pair of climbing rentals I got. I have been to several gyms and this rental pair was the worst I have smelled. For these reasons I didn't give it the highest review. However I think it would have been a better experience if I came with my own shoes, so I will definitely come back and try it out again (plus update my review).

This place is absolutely awesome!  I never thought I'd get into bouldering (I was a top roping fan) but this place has convinced me otherwise.  I originally bought a groupon deal to try it out and joined when the summer deal was going on (I later realized that they regularly offer some type of deal).  The staff is awesome and super friendly.  The place is divided into sections and one of the sections is changed every Tuesday so you never get bored with the routes.  Personally I never use the cardio or weight lifting equipment but it looks nice and isn't ever super crowded.  They have a dedicated slack lining area if you ever get bored of climbing.  The bathrooms are so nice (and clean)!!  They provide locks (you have to leave your ID with them while you are borrowing a lock so you don't run off with one).  I love the fact that there is street parking in addition to their parking lot so you aren't driving around forever.  99 Ranch is right next to Bridges so if you get hungry you can walk right over and grab a pastry or something to drink.  I'm planning on moving soon and am already lamenting the fact that there aren't any good bouldering places like Bridges nearby.Bottomline:  Definitely check out Bridges if you are remotely interested in bouldering (it is very affordable!) and if you have any doubts purchase a groupon first.

Oh how I love you, Bridges! Since moving to the Bay last summer, it's become my new regular climbing gym. Here's why: 1. It's all bouldering. While I miss top roping sometimes, the short but technical routes are perfect for my work out. I can come whenever I have a free hour on my own and get a quick fix, or go with friends and take turns on working through a problem. Besides, Iron Works and GWPC aren't far off if I need that top rope fix.2. The floors are so squishy! Makes sense since some of the boulder routes are super highball. I've taken many a fall from high up and am happy to say each time I was more surprised than hurt. Who would've thought I couldn't dyno my way up to that sloper?3. Atmosphere is everything, and the staff at Bridges are always chill, helpful, and friendly. The crowd (and occasionally there is a crowd, unfortunately) is almost always pleasant.Not to mention, Bridges offers a lot of options by way of slacklining areas, fitness classes, weights, and ping pong! The routes are changed frequently enough and range from traverses to dynos with everything in between. The terrain is well-varied as well (LOVE the cave, nothin' like spending an afternoon climbing across a ceiling). Bridges rocks!

[+] Great, friendly staff[+] Clean bathrooms, lockers, sauna[+] New Cybex weight equipment[+] They make their own juice[-] Fridays are $6 student nights- packs the house- so many UC students I couldnt even get on the wall =/[-] Everytime im there the juice bar/ cafe doesnt seem open

I've only been to a couple rock climbing places before and I have to say that the staff here are really great and they are the reason for the 5 stars. We are relatively new to rock climbing and a couple of the guys behind the desk were nice enough to show us how to belay and give us some pointers. They also have a slacking area which you don't see everyday and nice little weight room.
Not only are the bouldering routes top notch, the staff and other members are very friendly, and make for a fun, social environment to get a work-out in.

I knew I wasn't going to like this place when I first pulled into the parking lot. Everything is so crowded. If you're into bouldering then yeah, this place is probably for you. For me I was loured into the gym by a Yelp deal and the array of classes that they offered. I showed up Saturday morning for the pilates class held at the Yoga Tin Shed. Seriously, it was outside in a shed that was probably constructed by a free lancing hippie. There was no door knob! And the door wasn't even sealed completely, there was a huge gap at the bottom where a steady breeze would blow in and when there was a slight  gust of wind the door would swing open. Needless to say, I was cold 90% of the time. The class itself was not good. Felt more like a slow yoga class, choppy, lacked direction, little to no adjustments, there wasn't even enough equipment for the class. It probably didn't help that the class was comprised of what looked like a sea of moms. This place isn't for me, I will most likely not be returning.

Great place for a bouldering gym. I would come to this place more if it opened until 11pm  on the weekdays.Avoid coming Friday night because all the college students form Berkeley come here for the cheap admission. It's harder to find nice routes.The facilities are clean and doesn't smell like sweaty feet.The representative at the front desk are really nice and very helpful.A friend of a friend held a birthday party after hours. I didn't go but I'm considering it for my birthday. It would be nice to have a whole gym to yourself and your friends. Great idea for bonding.Parking is a little challenging since they have a small lot made for about 15 cars AT MOST. You either have to park in the street or the nearby plaza. I'm always worried that my car will be towed but it hasn't yet. On a rainy day, it sucks to walk to the gym from around the corner.I have not tried the slack lining but it looks like a lot of fun. Best part, you get to top out. None of the east bay rock gyms in the area allows you top out (Comparing to BIW and GWPC)

This place is amazing! I was a member for about a year and then I moved to the Peninsula. Now I truly miss Bridges. They shake it up constantly changing the routes to present new challenges. The location has the "local" feel with friendly staff and patrons. A great location for beginners and skilled alike. I truly miss the fun challenges Bridges bouldering offered. Hint: Hit Bridges when they open any day (even weekends) and you will find you will have the location almost to yourself).

I was pretty impressed with this bouldering gym. First thing I noticed was how tall the bouldering walls were and that all the problems topped out, you had to fully get on top of the boulder to finish, just like when you climb outside. The setting is really fun and interesting and they had great quantity and range of climbs, I had a good batch of routes to warm up on and some good ones to work as well.Another enticing aspect of the gym was the dedicated slack line area. When I was there they had 9 lines set up, all different heights and lengths. They even had "training" lines. My only complaint here is that they need a long one-inch slack line, the original style of slack line that many climbers still use.Overall, this is a great bouldering gym, and a good place to get some exercise and send some porbs.

No.  I purchased two Yelp Deals.  TWO!  That's how much I like this place.Rocks to top off.  Slacklines all around and ropes to swing on.  Sauna.  Fluffy crash floors.  An air of everybody can have fun and should. Right next to my weekly grocery store, 99Ranch.  Ample parking. Love. I like this place.  This is where I'd take my little sister, little cousin, or students to have fun and play.  For climbing: While this place isn't IW, Bridges features some decent routes for bouldering.  I must say that the top rope here is dreadfully lacking.  That's probably why they don't seem too concerned about making sure that you know how to belay.For anything but climbing: Bridges makes me feel like a kid again.

I almost forgot that I bought a Yelp Deal for Bridges Rock Gym last January.  So a couple days ago (less than 10 days before it was set to expire), I headed over to redeem the two vouchers I purchased - $25 for five day passes each (10 total).  Having heard great things about the gym from friends, I have been wanting to try the bouldering, slacklining, and various yoga, Zumba, and kick boxing classes that Bridges offers.   However, I have to admit that I was a bit disappointed and that my initial impression was more like three stars.  It is simply not on the same level as Ironworks.But I am giving Bridges four stars for the following reasons: 1) They are close and filled a previously unmet need for a gym in El Cerrito.  2) I really did have fun the two times I have come so far and the manager made a point to walk over to give me some good slacklining tips (I was crazy enough to try the high one).  3) I was impressed with their range of bouldering routes and have to admit that my skill level can't appreciate them all.  4) I can see how the facility would be a fun place to rent for a low key event given the variety of options they have including a kitchen upstairs.  5) They have saunas in the lockers rooms and on-site massage.  6) They are cheaper than Ironworks and they always seem to have different deals available - on Yelp, Groupon, and even in the Chinook Book.  That means it is pretty easy to find an even better deal.I also appreciate the fact that my vouchers only had to be redeemed by the 26th (my expiration date) but they don't actually expire once in the system.  Therefore I can take my time trying out different elements of the gym although I was prepared to try to go as many days as possible and beg various friends to come along - the nice thing being with the deal I got is that you can share or gift the passes.

This place is great all around!  The atmosphere is very non-competitive, so if you're a beginner you should not feel shy about coming here and checking this place out for the first time.  There is slack lining (with an area of ropes to assist you), traditional rock climbing, and solo rock climbing.  There's even a small workout room and an area to stretch/where they hold classes.  The people at the front desk are very helpful and friendly.  There are a variety of levels for all stages and difficulty of climbing, and I appreciate that the "courses" change pretty regularly.  I see all types of people coming here (watching am 9-year-old kid rock the level 10 climbs and slack line like a pro definitely produces an incentive for me to work hard and get as good as him).I always jump on the opportunity to get a Groupon deal for the place when I can.  I've been here more times than I can count and I will continue going until I make it to level 10+!

Gumby arms and a weak ankle, a good boulderer this makes not. Yet upon my recent visit I discovered that the security of a rope builds different strength and technique and that free climbing practiced different skills and strategy. It was also cool to see how challenging short top rope could be. Set up some more good stemming problems, and it'd be solid gold.The owner, Damien, an accomplished slackliner, happened to be around and was super welcoming and down to earth. He gave us insights into his personal interests (deep water free solo) and a behind-the-scenes perspective of the gym. It was in the locker room that I realized how genius he and Jeffie (his lovely wife) really are: immaculate, lots of privacy and a glorious sauna for all! There's really no need to ever leave. Palm some rock and get tired? Hop on the slacklines! Need a break? Check out the climbing vids and surf on the free wi-fi. Hit the wall again and need some extra juice? Grab a meal at the cafe!
