Want to wind down? Chillax in the sauna. Feeling flexible? Get into position with yoga. You can even bring along the kiddies as there's a toddler play area!I might just live here.

This place is awesome..I never knew this place existed until I had heard about it from a friend.. and I was so happy to find this place out! Yes, I'm that girl where an idea of a perfect date would be a day of rock climbing ..lol :)The whole place is huge complete with a pretty well equipped gym, zip lining, and they also offer classes like yoga, spinning, and kickboxing. However, I was here for the indoor bouldering and rock climbing. I've been to several rock climbing facilities prior to this, so I was happy to finally be able to find one close to home. The staff here are friendly and extremely helpful. It also wasn't that packed when I came in but im guessing that it was because it was a weekday. They offer different levels of difficulty for rock climbing, and I am nowhere near what you would call 'experienced'  lol.. only because because I mainly do it for just the fun and thrill..but the staff here are completely understanding and supportive. I can't believe people actually climb without a harness though...I, for one, am not that ballsy..haha. But I totally understand that when you get really good at something, you really want to push yourself to the limit. Anyways this place is great, definitely check it out especially if it's close to home. I had a blast here, and I'd surely be back with friends next time and do zip lining since that's next on my bucket list. They also have groupon deals that go on sometimes so keep a look out for those cause they offer really good prices! Now check this place out and go burn some calories!!!
Got the all day deal for bouldering. I only climbed for 45 minutes before getting tired, but still a great deal! They also have some training equipment for strength and grip.

I loved it. I was nervous--had never done bouldering before. The people were super helpful and the facility was great. The exercise equipment (treadmills and stuff) was a little small, but I didn't go there for that stuff. So no biggie.

freakin' sweet. a good friend of mine mentioned she had been rock climbing here, and I decided to switch up my exercise routine and give it a try. after all, my new years resolution was to do more shit. the yelp deal is fantastic; $25 for a three day pass, or you can bring a friend with you and that counts as one of the three. I guess this place is bouldering, which is different from rock climbing. you're not strapped into a harness or anything, you just climb a wall and if you fall there's a bunch of mats to catch you. the first time is HARD, especially if you're like me and have no upper body strength. your body uses all these muscles it has never worked before, and I only made it over the wall once. The second time, however, I made it several times and moved on to a higher wall. I like that there are different walls and routes set up so the place works for beginners and experts alike. It's very clean and the staff have all been very friendly and helpful. as an added bonus, they have cardio and weight machines, and there's a schedule of classes they offer (the kickboxing class definitely caught my eye). highly recommended!

This place is a hidden gem in the neighborhood. For how small/uncrowded it is, it is very affordable and they often have great deals going on. I'm not even a climber and I joined just for the cardio machines and yoga/Pilates classes. All the staff are super friendly and helpful, and overall it's just a really neat place.

I'm a noob when it comes to rock climbing, so take this review with a grain of salt. Bridges is a smaller rock gym than my normal one (Hangar 18 in LA), but it has plenty of challenging routes to try. i came before 3pm, so the day pass of $10 was really reasonable. The place definitely caters to those who prefer bouldering, as there are only six roped climbs, at least two of which are for kids. Speaking of kids, both my nieces, age 10 and 3, really enjoyed themselves...but not because of the climbing. They really enjoyed playing on the slacklines, and I must admit, I thought they were pretty cool too. But I wanted a workout so I stuck to the walls. Both of the main bouldering walls are higher than I'm used to, but the really thick padding on the ground is more than I'm used to also, so it's relatively safe if you fall. There were plenty of climbs to keep me interested, and there just happened to be a few experienced climbers at the gym at the same time and there didn't seem to be any shortage of climbs for them, either. There's also a pretty big cave section for those who like a good challenge. My wife isn't big into climbing, but did enjoy the yoga classes they have there, and any time I can take her with me to one of my activities, the better. So the combination of rock climbing, slack lining (think tight rope walking), yoga/pilates classes, traditional gym equipment (weights, treadmills, bikes, etc.) and an affordable day pass (regular memberships are ~ $45/month) gives Bridges a four-star rating from me.  I'd give it five stars if it were bigger and offered more rope climbs.
I do regular exercise here recently, a bit depressing and the stretching pad smells terrible on the 2nd floor. The other stuff are all good and taking different classes everyday is fun.

Great Bouldering Gym. I cannot think of any complaints to be honest. The price is very reasonable and the staff are super cool. All of them climb and you seem them around climbing often.  They have some other nice features like the sauna as well as clean showers.

The staff at Bridges are extremely rude to first timers. The woman that checked us in did not give us any information. The guy who took over for her at the front desk was at first rude but after a while he told us to follow the same color rocks for newbies.  I think the owner needs to train their employees on how to talk to customers particularly if they are new. The guy did recommend a class that sounds interesting but after our experience with the staff I think we will try elsewhere.

I first started going to Bridges around 2009 I think.  It still seemed pretty new and had a good dozen or so regulars that I saw most of the times I was there.  I believe most of them either worked there already, or eventually worked there.  I had never been climbing at all before (and not too fond of heights) and several of them would offer their encouragement to me and ask if I wanted them to help me before suggesting techniques to help me solve a problem.  I had been told that some other climbing gyms were frequented by elitist climbers that were more intense and unforgiving/unfriendly to beginners.  I'm so glad my friend brought me to Bridges instead.  The staff AND the regulars couldn't have been more welcoming, friendly and helpful.  I was a member and went several times a week for most of 2010 and part of 2011.  I loved every minute of it and even made friends with some regulars who often invited me on their trips to boulder outdoors!I just recently started going again and have decided it's completely worth it to travel even from Alameda to get to this gym (I despise traffic on 80 in either direction).  I can make a whole day of it with doing cardio in the mezzanine, then climb for a few hours, and take a nice sauna before I hit the showers!I'm really happy to see they've added a lot since I was last here.  A whole separate room with lots of regular workout machines, kickboxing classes, zumba, etc.  They have a massage room now, acupuncture on certain days, and they always had slacklining and the yoga classes.  I took a few yoga classes when I was member and loved it, although, more difficult than other yoga classes I had taken!  I think the instructor had geared it towards building upper body strength and balance to coincide with bouldering.  As for climbers walking below you or oblivious climbers, when it's busy, I often see employees walking around alerting people to be aware and I've nicely asked a few climbers myself to move in case I fall or so I can comfortably drop from a problem and everyone is always cool about it.  I suggest that if you are bringing someone new to this, you inform them of climbing etiquette.  It's really easy to research if you are unaware yourself.

This gym is pretty awesome.  Obviously the main attraction are the rock climbing walls, however they also have a variety of gym equipment and exercise classes.  They also seem prepared to handle birthday parties and events as well.This was the first time I'd been rock climbing and I always though you'd be in a harness, but I guess these walls aren't as tall as those I see on tv and there are huge mats underneath to catch you if you fall.  After reading some of these reviews I guess there is a difference between rock climbing and bouldering...which apparently a better description of what this gym offers.  It really doesn't look that high when you're standing looking up, however, once you're on the wall, it feels like you're on the edge of a cliff or something!  A great work out (my arms and hands started feeling like jelly after a while) and a great time!The Yelp deal can't be beat, but I think even regular price, it's pretty affordable.
Small but more friendly than other gyms, work out machines are sufficient, really good for bouldering, little crowded (which is good).

Bridges is a smaller gym compared to some of the other rock climbing gyms in Berkeley as well as the SF Bay Area; however, the tradeoff is that there's not quite as much foot traffic to this location so you can really hit up any wall you want without much waiting. Pros- Friendly, chill staff.- Great for beginners.- Nice location for North Berkeley / El Cerrito etc.- Not too busy, so you aren't feeling bored waiting for other climbers like at other gyms.- There's a small gym upstairs with treadmills and weights, etc.Cons- Since it's so small, I bet you would get bored quite easily should you get a subscription.- The rental is kinda gross, so buy your own shoes if you're planning on going climbing in the future.For experienced climbers- This place is mostly bouldering so keep that in mind.- I'd suggest going to this one only if the location is ideal for you.

With each visit to Bridges, I find myself liking this gym more and more. Friendly staff and a ton of bouldering problems, what more can you ask for? They recently invested in new gym equipment, bought new climbing shoes for customers to rent, the cafe Spread upstairs just opened, and every week I find myself faced with a wall with new problems! Lately they seem to be consistently setting new problems every week which gives me something to look forward to every week. And of course their College Friday deals--climbing for $5 and shoe rental for $3--can't be beat. If you're serious about climbing, you may want to avoid Fridays as that is when new climbers take over and have not learned climbing etiquette yet, but if you can put up with the crowd, Bridges on Friday has an energizing atmosphere that is worth trying!

Came here this past weekend with my friend. She bought the Yelp deal last week, so she wanted to use it, I bought another deal just because I brought in 2 others with me. This was my very first time rock climbing. I've only seen the rock climbing portion at City Beach in Fremont. Bridges has more paths than that. They have a large rock in the center of the gym and another that covers about two walls of the gym. With the four of us, we didn't get to try all of the paths (since a lot of them looked too difficult for beginners), but we spent a good 3 hours there. Their paths were color coded, so if you had no idea what you were doing, you can follow those colored tapes and somehow find yourself at the top. I wish that works as I was climbing. I was scared of heights and could not see anything when I just held myself up close to the wall. Luckily their floors are covered with this thick, fluffy cushioned mat, otherwise, I wouldn't dare to jump. They also have paths with a harness. I actually managed to go to the very top with those. For some reason, those rocks are not so easy to grab alone. For the experienced climbers, they do have a commentary book on the side where you can request for certain paths to be made.Bridges Rock Gym has two fitness rooms: one upstairs, one near the main entrance. There's a room with ping pong. Also a part of the gym is filled with balancing ropes. I glanced at their schedule of activities, they seem to also have yoga and zumba classes. Their staffs are friendly and helpful. Luckily the gym is not overly crowded like your typical 24 Hour Fitness. If you want machines that don't smell like sweat and possibly in mint condition, do come here to work out.The Yelp passes actually pays for your entire day's activities. It also include using their non-rock climbing facilities. And if you want to use it for rock climbing, shoes and chalk fees are included in the pass. Don't quote me on this part, read the fine print yourself. I'm definitely coming back to challenge myself.

I've been looking for a good rock gym since moving to SF and after doing many research and going to many gyms, I've decided that Bridges is not for me.It was great at first, I've been using my friends guest passes to climb at Bridges, saving money.  The pricing at this gym is the cheapest I've seen.  It's got a great vibe, the gym members are very friendly and there's a section dedicated to slacklining.  This place is mainly bouldering, no real rope climbing, even though there is a very small rope area that is pretty much useless and taking up space Bridges could've used for more bouldering.  The gym area is so tiny, it made me wonder why they even put it in at all.  Yoga here is good and it's separated from the climbing area but it's a hard to concentrate on the yoga when you can hear everything in the other building.After months of climbing at this gym, I realized that the sets have no flow, no cohesion.  At times, it's just painful and I can foresee an injury happening just by looking at the problems.  The way they rate their problems is inconsistent.  Some things will be incredibly easy even though it's rated hard and then it'll be extremely hard when it's rated easy.The one thing that really turned me off from this place was the behavior of one of their staff members.  I've seen him tell someone that they're doing a problem wrong.  If someone said that to me, that would have turned me off from climbing.  From all of my many years of climbing, there is NEVER a wrong way of doing a problem.  Bridges must've lost a member because after that incident, I never saw that person again.The second thing that same staff member did that really made me want to have nothing to with this place was that he encouraged bullying.  I was told he teaches the teen team.  During one of their sessions, the children started to approach one of the gym members and one by one, the children started to insult him.  I was appalled, he was teaching the kids bullying.  And he just stood there, as if he was letting those kids know that it's okay to do it.  At first, I thought it was a joke but the look on that members face clearly said otherwise.  I tried to approach that person to see if the children was just kidding around but he had left looking disgruntled and upset.  I asked his friend who had also witness the incident if that was the kids playing and he told me no.This staff member's behavior is unprofessional and appalling.  He has no respect for others.  As soon as someone leaves the gym, he would just bad mouthed them from behind the counter.  I lost a friend to bullying and here I see this brat encouraging it.  I hope the management at Bridges do something about this.  Bridges lost a potential member and my friends have decided to cancel their memberships.**UPDATE**8/31/2011I was told by a friend that the Teen Team coach, Dillon, was fired.  I was also messaged by the manager and owner, Damian, to apologize for this ex-staff members behavior and he expresses his concerns about my experiences at Bridges.  I love that owners and managers get involved with their businesses instead of staying on the sidelines.  It tells me that they take criticism, even harsh ones like mines, in a good way.However, for it to take this long, 6 months, to see any kind of action is worrisome.I may be paying Bridges a visit again, maybe.**UPDATE**

I've been coming to Bridges for the past 6 months or so and I've been more than happy with my experience so far. I come here mainly for bouldering and I love the plethora of problems that await me on my next visit. They re-set the walls every so often so you can never complain that you've run out of problems to do. The floor padding is cushiony, the facilities are clean, there are showers and a sauna, a cafe upstairs... Top that off with a friendly and awesome staff (yay Jacky!) and community of climbers and you've got yourself a nice gem of a rock gym.Also, Friday nights ($5 only!) are a great night to bring your friends and peers who are new to the climbing scene and have them all try it out. I used to come every Friday night until I got hooked and just bought a membership. For those that are interested, there are is also a small area for top-rope climbing, a dedicated slacklining area (for when your arms are dead from climbing) and a gym area upstairs stocked with some basic machines and free weights.

Great bouldering gym!My boyfriend knows how much I love the indoor climbing and surprised me with a 10-pass to this gym and to experience my hobby together with me. Now, I'm a loyalist and I've held memberships with other local bay area rock gyms  and I was a little reluctantly to try out Bridges just because I had so much love for the other places.BUT.... after trying this gym out just twice now, I've loved it! The ppl who come here are very chill and everyone i've encountered here has been nice. There are a lot of kids here, but even they haven't gotten on my nerves yet, there are just so many trials I lose my concentration in , the screaming kids kind of "fade" into the background. haha. This gym is great for bouldering, and has expanded it's collection of weights, but if you're looking for lot of rope climbing and belaying, this may not be the place for you.  Enjoy!

I think this place is awesome!  If I lived closer, I would definitely get a membership.  This place has a good amount of workout equipment, a ping pong table, and of course the rock walls.  This was my first time in a rock climbing place, and it was definitely a challenge.  One of my favorite things was the slacklining area.  My first time doing it, and I was hooked.  The staff was very cordial and helpful as well!Anyways, I wanted to keep this review short.  =)

I've been coming to this gym for 2 years now and they just added a massage therapy service. Over the past couple of months, I have used this service a few times and it is amazing how much it has helped with my workouts. The therapist, Heather, does deep tissue massage that just melts my knots away. Now I can run faster and farther as a result and knowing that she can do her magic on my muscles after a long training run.Cost is a bit less than Massage Envy. But of course it is not as quiet since it is in a rock gym.

Started climbing here on a whim as a noob with my husband and fell in love with this place.  It's basically all bouldering (the top rope area is tiny), but there's a cave, some pretty high bouldering walls, and really interesting routes.  There's tons of gym equipment and treadmills, etc (that I never use), a diverse array of classes (I've liked some of the yoga and pilates classes; Tia is great) and a huge slacklining area.  There's a decent sized parking lot, discounts for college students on Friday nights, saunas in the bathrooms, free towels and locks, ping-pong events, and the price is unbeatable for a gym.   Tuesday and Friday night climbs are super busy, but the weekend mornings are chill.The best part is the people.  All the climbers and staff are incredible friendly and helpful.  People are constantly helping strangers and cheering them on.  It feels like friends!

this is THE place to boulder. it is SCARY to climb hard problems on the big rock in the middle of the floor. that rock goes higher than their pretty wimpy lead climb wall. but don't come here to lead climb anyway.great staff. just watch out for the crazy little kids running around in their camp during summertime.

I've been here two separate times. Most recently a day after a week of roped rock climbing. I didn't have as much fun as I did the first time, but that was because I was not as willing to take the same risks that I would when attached to a rope. Both are definitely different, both are definitely fun. You can make up for this risk aversion by trying the slacklining. Challenging! I noticed on my second visit that they added a rope that you can hang on to with your hand as you walk across the slackline. I think this is a mistake, as it will hinder your progress in the long run, though in the short term it will get you across the slackline. I've only seen one girl working the front desk, she is very nice and is happy to give you tips and advice, all you have to do is ask.

While visitng the Bay on business I dropped into Bridges on the recommendation of a friend.  It was $10 before 3p on weekdays, quite the bargain.  They had a January special going for $45 a month gym membership no initiation fee, which I would happily pay if I lived in the area and had very limited access to local climbing. The staff is quite friendly and the gym is farirly new.  The locker room even has a sauna.My main gripe is that the ratings here are highly variable depending on who set the routes.  I am not a V3 climber and could do some of the V3s without much groveling.  I was told this was partly due to less experienced route setters and route setters that 'didn't climb outside'.  If you want routes more reflective of outdoor ratings in areas such as the Tablelands (a.k.a. Happy/Sad Boulders) of Bishop look for stuff put up by Chris B, Rowan and most of Michelle G's routes.  If you want an ego boost stick to the other routes.

Not much for kids, especially under 10. I brought my 5 year-old son and his 8 year-old cousin. Under 14 are not allowed on the free-standing boulders, which is about half the gym. We were also not allowed to do any roped climbs, as they "have no process in place" for checking out (my) belaying skills. (The roped area is miniscule, but would be good for kids.) For my five year old, even the "VB" problems - of which there are 3 or 4 - proved too difficult. We made the best of it but I wouldn't come back with kids. I should have trusted my instinct and gone elsewhere once I walked into the place, but the kids didn't want to get back in the car. FWIW, I've been climbing for 25 years. There was a summer camp going on while I was there and there seemed to be a lot of showmanship going on on the part of the instructors, especially on the slack lines. I joined Yelp just to post this review.

We took 5 9-year olds to Bridges Rock Gym for our son's birthday party. The boys had a terrific time on the climbing walls and on the slack lines. The fee was very reasonable and, more importantly, the support couldn't have been better or more friendly. "Alec" supervised, instructed and belayed our kids and did a really good job of it. He was encouraging to the boys, including one who was a bit frightened and reticent, while, at the same time, maintaining control and keeping them from doing anything endangering to themselves or others. He was wonderfully patient and understanding...and trustworthy. The birthday package we purchased entitled our little group to an hour of supervised climbing and then an hour at their indoor picnic tables to share food. You're allowed to bring in your own. However, we didn't want to do the food thing as we were taking the boys to the Parkway theater for movie and lunch after climbing, so we arranged for our kids to be able to climb on the non-belayed  climbing walls. We were told that if we wanted supervision for that hour there'd be an extra charge. We decided to supervise ourselves, but Alec came over even though he didn't have to and he stayed with us for the second hour on both the climbing walls and the slack lines, as well. In the meantime, the manager, whose name I didn't get, was all over us seeing to it that everything was going well for our kids. I was struck by how gracious and attentive he was, particularly considering that the place was quite busy and he had a lot more to do than to take care of us.Our sons have climbed at a number of rock gyms. Mission Cliffs in SF is more impressive than Bridges as its climbing walls are probably 2-3X higher than at Bridges and there are far more of them, but, on balance, we'll be going back to Bridges in part because it's really quite nice and in part because the people there made it a very positive experience. At Mission Cliffs and some of the other places, they seemed to get lost in the crowd. At Bridges, that didn't happen to them, nor, as far as we could tell, to anyone else.We highly recommend this place for kids; great place for birthday parties.

While Bridges tries really hard to compete in the fierce climbing gym market of the Bay Area, it really falls short.  It has some major pluses; the staff is incredibly friendly, there is the option to "top-out" (finish your climb on top of the wall and then walk back to the floor), and the location is very convenient for anyone living in El Cerrito, Albany, and North Berkeley. However, even though this place is only a five-minute walk from my house and GWPC is a minimum of a twenty-minute drive, there's just not enough here to make me switch from Touchstone. The gym is almost all bouldering, with only a couple top-rope options. The fitness equipment is sorely lacking; there are mostly machines with a huge lack of free weights.  And, the classes are pretty sparse.  This is a nice place to spend an afternoon or evening bouldering, but there are better options in the East Bay if you are looking to join a climbing gym.

I just wanted to add to all the love everyone has for this place.I've been coming here for at least a year now and I can't think of anything bad to say about this place. It's a large bouldering space- and the wall problems change around every 2 weeks. They have a slacklining area, workout classes, and fitness equipment. Their facilities are really nice and they constantly upgrade the space- whether it's hanging artwork on the walls, providing new rental shoes or having cubicles for visitors to put belongings. The staff is always friendly and attentive and I don't think I'll ever find a better gym at a more affordable price!

Likes: Fun.  You can boulder, rock climb, balance rope, etc downstairs, or gym it upstairs, or use the sauna included in the ladies locker room.  I had fun bouldering since I'm a beginner.  $3 shoe rental is pretty reasonable to me.Dislikes: There's a locker room but I didn't have a locker so I had to leave my nice stuff in a corner like some other people did, and I didn't feel too comfortable about that

only 4 stars because i've only been taking yoga classes here =)First i've gotta say that I am not a yoga guru or anything, just an amateur. All the classes are for all levels, so really no pressure on how low you could bend! eiei..    The main yoga instructor, Molly, is the best. She's got a soothing voice, a qualification that all yoga instructors should have. It really makes a difference! The transition between the poses moves rather smoothly..  But the rest of the instructors are also pretty good and now they actually hired more instructors, and each one has different approach to yoga which can actually help you from getting bored of the same routine. Their facilities are nice and clean. The only thing I wish they have is wall mirror in the yoga studio. so we can check out our poses or our behinds sometimes?? huhuhu...
Never crowded, staff is always friendly, and the climbs are very thoughtful. They have fresh courses every week. Definitely a repeat visitor.

Had a great time here.  Good if you want to do free climbing (no harness), not so much if you want a place to workout.  The floors are just big squishy mats and they have all the different levels of climbs routed with colored tape.There is also a wall where you can belay if you are into that.  Also, a couple tight wires.Reasonable prices and worth checking out.

What's there to not like about Bridges?The staff and other climbers here are very friendly.  The problems are fun, challenging, well-rated, and the option of topping out is a huge plus!  It really adds an extra dimension to every problem.  Also, the holds aren't greasy (they're very well kept, actually), and the 4 dedicated slacklines give you something to do when you need to take a break from the walls.  I haven't used the gym equipment upstairs, but they appear to be well kept too, and I never hear any complaints about them.  Just beware of Friday nights here--although it is discounted to $5, all the UC Berkeley clubs, along with other rabid groups of college students come and swarm the walls, creating long waits and potential hazards.  They do step aside if you ask them to, and they usually climb themselves out after an hour or so.Also, after climbing at some rock gyms in other states and countries, I'd have to say that Bridges has spoiled me rotten.  It's truly one of the best.
I LOVE THIS GYM everyone is so friendly and helpful. They offer so many classes, and way more things like slack lining and rock climbing OBVIOUSLY lol. But definitely check this gym out.

I like this place but some people that come in are down right oblivious to people climbing around (and sometimes above) them. When I'm climbing in the overhang area, I end up above people. It's a safety issue and really annoying.

EDIT:  Since I posted this review, Bridges has completely fixed the problems that I had with the gym.  Children are now given proper instruction before coming in, and they've set up specific areas for the kids to climb in.  They also stitched the pads where I sprained my ankle, so I'm satisfied.  I put these comments in the comment box here and they tried really hard to fix the problems.  Thank you.ORIGINAL REVIEW:This place is fantastic.  When I first started coming It was a lot quieter and better kept.  I just have a few complaints.  I sprained my ankle here really badly because there is a tear on one of the seams that they haven't fixed.  Foot went right through the pad and slammed against the concrete floor.  The guy there told me that I should have checked the pads before I climbed... Isn't it their job to maintain the place and make sure it's safe for the climbers?I have also noticed that the kids there can get really dangerous.  They're always running underneath me or climbing into me while I'm on the wall.  They should give them a list of rules before they allow them inside.Besides these two little gripes, I've had a great time there.  I go about four to five times a week, and have for quite a while.  I plan to continue going there for years to come.  It's much quieter than iron works, and it's a lot more comfortable atmosphere.  They frequently put up new problems, and I think they're getting much more interesting than when I first started coming.

It took me one visit to sign up for monthly membership here.  They charge ~35 bucks a month for unlimited access to the bouldering facilities, gym, and yoga facilities.  They specialize in bouldering and slack-lining, but their gym amenities are decent (complete set of free weights, benches, and various cardio equipment).  I haven't taken a yoga class with them, so I'm not too sure how their studios are.  One thing that is incredibly obvious, is that their facilities are CLEAN.  Their restrooms are WHITE and SHINY.  Their water-fountain doesn't have any nasty gunk from extensive use.  Not a single one of their free-weights are rusty.  I'd say that's as good as it gets when it comes to gym provisions.  It's literally located in the back yard of Pacific Mall (Ranch 99 Market) in (technically) Richmond*.  I usually go every week and do some bouldering, just prior to grabbing some groceries at Ranch 99.  Makes for an efficient and convenient stop right off the I-80.  As with most gyms, the standard "if you die, you may not sue us, and you indemnify us from any fault/liability relating to your death" waiver  applies.  Fortunately, everybody who frequent Bridges Rock are very mindful, courteous, and respectful of the other gym users.  It's definitely a great place to frequent.  *The entire block of land that Pacific Mall is built on was purchased from the City of El Cerrito by the City of Richmond.  The block of land is now referred to as the "Richmond Annex."  Though it is geographically smack dab in the middle of El Cerrito, it is technically part of the City of Richmond.

NOTE- this review is based on using a yelp coupon.  A little on the small side, but overall it was a fun time.  Reminds me of how out of shape I am, and how in shape this place could get you.  Went with the fiancee and our other married friends.  Seemed like everyone had a fun time.  Make sure you're in shape or you will be tired quick!

I am a complete beginner at rock climbing so when Groupon came up with 3 passes to Bridges I thought it was the perfect way to try a new sport. I came here on a Sunday at about 2pm and it was pretty packed with people. For a beginner it can be a little intimidating cause it is bouldering (or climbing without ropes). The front desk was nice and pretty much told us go have fun and explained the markings on the rocks (which I didn't get at first but then it began to make sense how the routes are labeled). I never realized how much strength it takes to climb and some of the girls out there were amazing. It looked like they had been climbing forever. I actually liked the tight rope more than climbing! It was really fun and so were the rings that you can hang off of. The gym as a whole was set up well and the bathrooms were kept clean. Sunday afternoon was a little busy for a beginner so I might try a different night next time. It would have helped a little being shown the set up of the wall but I am sure if I asked they would have been more than accommodating. They also had a special to add on classes which was great!

LOVE this place...I was ready to join for the year after about 4 Yoga sessions with various instructors. I'm also doing CrossFit, so really wanted to add the Yoga for the stretching, balance and focus. They have a room full of machines...but since I CrossFit,  I haven't checked this out yet. They offer climbing classes, massage (you pay extra for this), and a sauna and showers (which is included). The bathroom, showers and sauna are always clean. Big brownie points from me on this...and the staff at the counter are always friendly and helpful. :)

I bought a 5/$25 bundle from Yelp's deals and couldn't be happier. Friendly staff and lots of different obstacles from beginner to advance. This guy I talked to while being scared shitless at the top of the rock said that one of the good things about this rock gym is that you can "top out", as in you can climb over the rock like in a real life situation.  I look forward to coming back.Cons: hyper kids running around and stinky rental shoes.

I absolutely love this place.  The staff is very nice and its clear they love what they do and are happy to be there.   The classes are always small so you get tons of one on one attention. The weights and machines are always available.  The best part about this gym, is after a long workout you can sit in the sauna.  Love this place!

This is one of those places that I keep meaning to review, but have never gotten around to. I've been coming here, on and off, since 2011. Finally joined up in 2012.The basics: it's primarily a bouldering gym, with a half wall devoted to top roping/belaying. There's an area for slack lining and they've slowly added on additional things over the years. There's now a weight room, a cardio and free-weight area, a place to lounge, and a separate yoga studio. There are full locker rooms (and you can borrow locks at the front desk for free) with showers that are always kept clean. There's also saunas and a massage room on hand, for those of you interested additional perks.Gym membership (for which there are always good deals happening) gets you into EVERYTHING, including a slew of classes, from yoga to kickboxing. You also get a free guest pass once a month, the better to lure your friends with.The intangibles: what sets Bridges apart from most other gyms is the excellent job they do at fostering the feel of community. They've got a great Halloween party, host climbing events. The guys and girls at the desk are always friendly, know your name, and willing to give advice on problem routes or even who to take the steps as a beginner to being a better climber. The attitude seems to carry over to members. People are always willing to help out, point out next steps, cheer you on.  Parking is a little sparse, but you can always park at the Ranch 99 lot.Overall, 4.5 stars with the parking situation and lack of a full cafe being a minor, but important, issues.Join up, start climbing. Your arms will simultaneously hate you and thank you for it.
Great bouldering gym altogether. The route difficulty levels are sometimes inconsistent, but there a lot of options. Great place to go on Fridays! 4.5/5

I come here mostly for bouldering, typically on Fridays when their day passes are $5, and the equipment rental's $3.  They have bouldering, indoor-climbing, slack-lining, rings, and this weird pvc container that has water in it (which you try to lift and hold above your head for as long as you can.  My personal best was 2:13).  They change the climbing routes typically every week or so, and it's always a great place to go with friends.  The staff here are also all very knowledgeable and friendly!
This place is sooo personal and friendly! My kids love it here.. A place where the whole family can workout and have fun at. Too bad I've moved out of the area or I would be a regular.

Had I not fallen off the top of a wall without a spotter, which is my own fault, I would return.Minus my trauma, there's a lot to do here. Bouldering, rock climbing, slacklining... They have cardio machines upstairs, massages, and yoga and fitness classes! So whatever your mode of fitness, it looks like it's here!

I make it a point of going to climbing gyms whenever I'm traveling to check out the ambiance and local scene. I'd have to say that the feeling at Bridges is much more chill than at the Touchstone gyms in the Bay area, what a welcome change! The people here were very friendly and didn't seem to have something to prove like people in some climbing gyms. I expected a bouldering gym to be filled with macho types, but that was not the case. The only downfall of this place is that very few routes had a good flow to them. I was climbing VB-V1 so perhaps the routesetters take more care in the higher ratings. I'd go back here next time I'm in the area for sure.

This place is awesome! Today was my very first visit! I came with 3 other friends. We had the Groupon and it was a great price and includes shoes and chalk so that's a plus! At first it looked so intimidating and I fell on my behind and back a few times before getting a hang of it. It also helps that it was labelled and two of my friends are regulars so they knew what was hard and easy. It's hard work but it was super fun and I'd love to come back again!

I have never climbed before but I had to do it for a project. My first time there went well. It was nice because they open 7 days a week. The staff there are friends and the bathroom is very clean and well kept. Overall it is very fun and I had such a good deal on Yelp!

I've recently started coming here regularly to boulder. It's pretty crowded on Fridays because of their $6 deal, but it's less crowded earlier in the week and in the mornings. The problems are fun, fair and challenging and the cushion they provide makes bouldering here very safe. I've fallen from at least 15 feet and haven't gotten hurt. The staff here is friendly and they provide decent workout space & gym equipment. Overall, this is a great place to start bouldering- and they have a large range of problems for the advanced climbers as well.

After moving from southern California in August, my first order of business was finding a quality climbing gym.  However, I was not expecting the ridiculous prices (70$ per month with 100$ initiation fee...really??).  I had been paying about 30$ a month down in LA and was NOT going to pay almost triple that. I began climbing exclusively outdoors for the next few months before hearing from a climbing partner about a Groupon special Bridges was having.I checked it out and have been hooked since.  Not only is the price affordable (45$ per month) but they also regularly have Groupon specials (I bought a ten pass card for 45$!!).  A huuuuge plus is that there is also slacklining and saunas in the locker rooms!  Before I had hardly been in a sauna; I am now an addict.The only real downside is that the roped climbs are pretty much worthless but that is something I can live with until Touchstone and other companies decide to get off their high horses and stop charging prices only rich kids' parents and the bay area elite can afford.

a great place to unwind, blow off some steam, rediscover how out of shape i am. i climb some and then play around on the slack lines, take a few falls and head out for lunch. i'm pretty much recreational climber? but they've had enough yelp/groupon/living social deals that i don't need to pay for a membership, which is nice. i appreciate that. i also like that they're situated next to 99 ranch where i can stop off and get a boba or something after a climb. i have not tried their classes, massage, but i do like how they've expanded their offerings with some more gym equipment and the cafe. bridges is definitely a nice place to go and get some exercise with some friends. their staff is friendly, knowledgeable, and can offer useful advice when solicited.  makes me think i should take a couple of their classes though, huh?anyhow, i kinda wish their membership was a bit cheaper, but i guess it's geared toward the frequent climbers. i'll survive on my yelp deals for now and hope they keep offering them up every year.

This place is super fun. I really like the slacklining parts and the owner is pretty great.  They also have some awesome bouldering, I'm told, but I don't boulder.The classes are varied and fun, and I wish I'd taken more of them when I was in that area.  Great gym at a great price owned by a small local owner.  Give em some love! Woot! Bridges

wow, this gym has a little bit of everything!  yes, its a rock gym, and that takes up the majority of space and energy, but there is also gym equipment, treadmills, classes (zumba, yoga, pilates, and bouldering, to name a few) and massage!  the people here were very nice, the facility was clean, and altogether, it was a fun (and challenging) way to exercise with friends!note: this place is a a TOTAL bargain, but you can just check out the website for that info: bridgesrockgym.com/?q=pr…

LOVE this place. I walked in brand new to rock climbing and was welcomed by a super friendly, relaxed staff. It definitely has a community feel to it--I've walked into some of the bigger Touchstone gyms around the Bay and felt a bit overwhelmed by the crowds and size of them all. I can hang out and climb at Bridges for hours at a time and make a few friends along the way. The problems, showers, yoga classes, and other amenities are all quality. Check it out!

I've been a member of a couple climbing gyms in the Bay area and I hate to say it, but people who belong to climbing gyms seem to be really elitist jerks!  And if they aren't jerks, cause they all aren't, then there's just too many of us in one place!I really like Bridges because it's small and cozy and seems more mellow and family oriented.  I hate writing this review because I'm scared it will become popular and crowded...Oh well...I like the yoga classes too, that little room is so 'state of the art'; everything is clean and new.  The people who work here are so nice, as well.The owner checked me in one day and I had no idea until I was introduced to him later.  Feels like a 'small family business' and those are the kind I like!
Great place. un real for all the rock climbing fans. if the had a little bit bigger weight room i would have given it 5 stars.
excellent gym and great customer service. manager took great pains to resolve a billing issue for me.

I thought everyone who worked at this gym was great and the walls had tons of intricate bouldering problems. When I climb that high, I like top-roping better (only because I'm scared! haha), but if you're a big boulder fan, this place is perfect. I enjoyed the slacklines a lot and some of the other people using them, as well as employees, showed me and my friend how to use them. It's a little bit confusing to find the place - it's tucked away in the corner of a strip mall area - but once you do, it's easy to get back to later.
I've been here twice so far. The staff is very nice and friendly, as well as the members that I talked to. The space is great too!

I have been to a lot of climbing gyms when I travel for work and this one is the best I've been to away from home. Cool thoughtful routes that call for a variety of different techniques (I'm an intermediate climber, V3-V5 if that means anything to you), friendly members and staff (which is so nice when you need some help with a route), and the gym is small but well-rounded. I feel like it would be a terrific place to start out as a climber, and I think bouldering is SUCH a better way to start climbing than using the ropes - no fussing with 1000 things, no waiting on your flaky friend to meet you, just the (fake) rock and you. Try this place out and I bet you'll be hooked.

I came here with two ppl. Joe was super super nice ! All the stars are for him .They don't have harnesses here . Though I don't think I'll be returning bc the white loud lightweight flamboy dude rubbed my friends the wrong. They said he was being kind of a bitch about me attempting my third time over a slight tilt wall. I didn't really hear anything he was saying bc my adrenaline was going due to the fact that I WAS really really high and I was about to drop. So we prob won't be back since he was kind of a dick. We'll go back to diablos rock gym

My friend bought me 3 day passes to this gym for my birthday!  Let me tell you, it's AWESOME!!!  They have bouldering, rock climbing, slacklining, yoga, and a gym area with cardio and weights.Bouldering: The gym is mostly bouldering, which I was nervous about but after a couple of days of bouldering I'd say I prefer it over climbing!  The mats on the floor are super cushion-y so it's very safe to fall.  They also have a lot of "over-the-top" bouldering where you climb over the top edge.  They also change the courses pretty frequently.Climbing: Not as many courses but still a good amount.  Most people are bouldering so when you do climb you pretty much have the whole rock to yourself!Slacklining:  They usually have 3 lines set-up of 3 different heights and lengths!  I tried slacklining for the first time here!  It's really fun!  You have to try it if you haven't yet!Haven't used the gym area or yoga classes yet.Staff here is very nice and helpful.  And since the gym is fairly new, there isn't that many people which is nice.  But I'd imagine that it will get more popular soon and probably more crowded.

The gym IS pretty cool with Yoga, rock wall and some machines and classes. I Originally gave it a low rating because of problems with charges. Since they have taken care of it after reading my YELP review. I kicked it back up.

I suspect all the other reviewers refer to the wonderful lady sitting behind the counter as "Damian's wife" because of her unusual name: JEFFIE!Everyone who works here is super-friendly, and the gym is spotless.  You also don't have to worry about dragging crash pads around with you when working on problems because there's thick wall-to-wall padding.Another tidbit of information that hasn't been mentioned yet: Bridges is located right by a causal carpool location so you can be chauffeured into the city in the mornings after climbing and showering!  Check it out here: ridenow.org/carpool

Amazing.This place is just incredible. Kudos to Damien, his wife, and their partners for getting such a fun place built and being such nice people*.The classes they offer are great and really informative. Take one and you're sure to improve in climbing / slacklining / pastry eating (this one is self-taught in the cafe).The more you explore, the more fun things you find. On the surface, this place is a bouldering gym (large rock structures where you "top out" over the top of the rock) which some vertical rock-climbing roped walls. If you look around, you'll find some lines strapped in at knee level, which turn out to be for slacklining - one of the funniest activities i've ever done.Upstairs, they have a loft which has a couch and flat-screen TV to watch DVDs. There's also Anne's Cafe where delicious smoothies are served. Sometimes they even have free samples, baked fresh in their ovens! There are also rowing machines, free weights, treadmills, and Precor machines. Explore some more and you'll discover that they have yoga 7 days a week, in the brown Yoga shed next door. Finally, you'll find some gymnasts rings that have been put up in the corner. Great for doing inverted pull ups / push ups and general ring work... I look forward to doing the Iron Cross one day.The other people who climb here are also really cool and friendly people. It really feels great when you get a random person encouraging you to finish the trail that you're climbing. This place could easily feel  like a "home".I saw the owners putting on a Birthday party one day and they were super nice and friendly to the partiers. Fun Fact: Damien is actually in one of the slacklining posters that hang up on the wall.*I am not connected with / employed by / related to in any way to this business.Oh yea, there's also a day-care / play area, sauna, showers, men's / women's locker room, and they have fresh towels available.
i love the bouldering possibility! The people who climb here and the staff are friendly and gave me tips on how to slackline as well.

Got a yelp deal, woot woot! How about a 5passes for $25 yelp deal at Bridges??? Woot da woot da woooot woooooot!!!!I opted to invite my 2 sisters and 2 more sistahhhs/friends to go with me and redeem this yelp deal  to share the thrill and exhilaration of my first indoor bouldering experience; as my birthday celebration, no less: and partly to be okay with the embarrassing falls and not-quite climb attempts I was fearing I'd have...and yes I had them.  We were all first timers and Joe, the staff there at that time, was very encouraging and helpful in getting us geared right (and by that I mean, sized and matched with this black leather, sweat-smelling climbing shoes) and also get started with the walls. One sister was really a natural, she was up there in no time like a spider monkey. And so was another friend. The beauty of this place is that there are other friendly patrons that gave us the space and time we needed to conquer that first wall as warm up. Then as a team, we opted to step up the challenge a notch and tried the opposing wall which had a room for us all to be up the boulder, so to speak, and enjoy the would be view (if there were any, say, sky and mountain ridges whathaveyou: but in there it was fluorescent lights and the ceilings, which was a okay) Still, Joe was checking up on us and was encouraging. We had so many questions about the markings on the walls and the difficulty level of each color in the indoor rock wall. We had time goofing off on our attempts to conquer the beginner pegs to the intermediate ones. We got so carried away, we were helping my sister  map out expert tracks 18 feet up on the hardest wall with the steep angle...she made it...or so we thought, her arms gave her away on her last reach up top. Needless to say my spider monkey sister freefell from 18 feet up and landed thankfully, on both feet! Thank goodness, with no injury. You don't get a harness when you do most walls; that's why its more bouldering, really than it is rock climbing.  But there is one section where you could try climbing with the harness and belaying; but very limited spots and it wasn't quite inviting as the bouldering walls.We tried the slacklines as well and that was loads and loads of fun and laughter as we each tried to shake less and cross the lines with little help from ropes and we struggled with cool, calm and collected steps to cross the lines.If you've tried bikram yoga before you'd be used to the sweaty smell of the shoes...but other than that, it was awesome.

Things I like about this place:It's not that crowdedThey specialize in bouldering and it's awesome The slackliningThe gym at the top of the stairsCan buy half off coupon in bulk onlineLocationNot sure if I like these things so much:The topping outNo top ropingBit pricey
Friendly workers and a great variety of routes.

Great bouldering gym.  The ratings seem pretty consistent within the gym and there's a wide range of terrain and difficulty to choose from.   Even though already have a climbing gym that is closer, I'd visit this gym whenever I need a change of scenery.

Been coming for a little over a year. Great place to boulder and slackline. I don't really use their weights or cardio equipment, but it is a good option to have. I have been to a few of their classes and they are pretty good. All in all, a chill, comfortable environment to climb.

Don't think I need to say much about this place because it seems the general consensus is that it's great.  Love that it's all bouldering, love that they cater to locals (families) even though I'm not one for kids myself, love that they lowered their prices when the economy went bust, even love the photo exhibit they have up.  Love that it's super close to my house and that membership includes yoga, running club, and free intro to slacklining - which I still have to take.  They've also got an impeccable ladies' room complete with sauna.I like that they have a cafe upstairs though I've never hung out there.  The workout space is a little tiny, but I don't really use it so it's not a big deal to me.Most importantly, everyone who works here and climbs here is super friendly and just generally seem like good people.  It's a good sized space and intimate at the same time -- you can always count on someone to give you beta or encouragement when you need it.

This is a review for their YOGA studioI didn't catch the instructor's name, which is unfortunate because she was wonderful.  She's a beautiful black lady -- dunno if that helps anyone :)Anyways, I'll break this down into 3 parts, the instructor, the class, and the space.The instructor is wonderful, she really sets a wonderful atmosphere for the class.  It is light but focused.  She cracks a lot of hilarious jokes and has great taste in music.  She makes it a point that she will go around to help adjust people but she won't be offended if you say "no thank you" or "play dead" if you don't want help.  I got only one adjustment but it was a helpful one!The class, the actual class didn't feel challenging, but seeing as how my shoulders are a bit sore today I might be lying.  It was one of the least crowded yoga classes I've been to, based on size and number of people and personal space.The space, man so this is a big studio -- it's a converted shed and in March it was still really cold.  It had no insulation and the heat escaped really quickly.  Someone mentioned that this was warm compared to in January -- I was kind of miserable.  Yoga should be practiced in a warm room (ideally) and it is much better for your muscles.  It has some fake wood flooring on cement (HARD and COLD) so keep that in mind.  The ceilings are an eyesore but not a big deal.  The main thing was how cold it was.The other part that was distracting, was during savasana you could hear people in the gym clearly and loudly.  Not very relaxing and mind freeing.  They also had music playing in the gym really loudly (it was a good song at least) but again, it kind of lost the point of savasana I think.So yea, I probably wouldn't come back.  I lucked out with parking but there isn't much space to park nearby.  There is the bonus of being close to Ranch 99 though =)

If you are thinking of joining this gym in order to take yoga or pilates, think again. The classes are held in an unheated outbuilding (tin shed) that is not heated. The floor is good, and the instructors are good, but the room is frequently in the 50-degree range. I was one of the earliest members of the gym when it opened, and I was very excited at first. But after *years* of being told the heat situation would be resolved, I have become very frustrated. It's to the point that the instructors ask the class participants to ask the gym owners for heat. I still go to the gym, because it is convenient for me, the rates are very reasonable, and like the facility in general. But if I want to take a class, I wear lots of layers, and bought special yoga socks that grip the mat because with no socks the room is cold enough my toes go numb.  And it's not just me -- you have never seen such an array of creative attempts to keep feet from freezing while doing yoga. The owners did buy a couple of space heaters for the shed, but the heaters take a long time to warm the room, and the owners do not turn them on in advance of classes. They will tell you that they do turn them on in advance, but I am telling you from first-hand experience that they do not.  On Wednesday of this week, I arrived for an evening class, the heaters were off, and the room was 59 degrees. Yesterday, I arrived for a 10 AM class, same situation.  Be warned, they will tell you that the situation has been resolved -- I have been told this a minimum of 5 times -- but, the room is still very cold.
This gym is smaller than others, but very well maintained and nicely run. The people who worked there are really nice and helpful.

I'm not a climber, but I still love this gym. I use it for the classes and the weight room. This is not one of those gyms where you'll see rows of people sweating away on ellipticals praying to be skinnier. Nor will you see men loitering about the weight room trying to catch sneaky glimpses of their ripped arms. This is a friendly gym with the sound of kids voices as they encourage each other on at the slackline, a gym with good music, and with enough classes and equipment to keep those of us non-climbers plenty happy.

This place rocks! Went there for the first time a few days ago. So much fun for a good price and for pretty much as long as you want. They have a gym, a section to walk tight ropes, and best of all, rock climbing. Definitely plan to go back a million times.

This is all about bouldering and it was fun. I've been wall climbing pretty often, but never spent time bouldering. It is fun, but calls for caution than I was used to. Being more aware of where your next step and reach will be with no harness! This was way harder than what I was used to. If a big guy like me can do this...anyone can if they just try. A great work out and most definitely a fun group activity. We will definitely try bouldering again. This spot is great because the employees are extremely well versed in what they do and are very friendly.

Loved the new workout. I can't believe this place is just down the street from me! An El Cerrito fitness hidden treasure. The amenities are great and the line and climbing make this a great place to add an extra workout to your routine. I hit muscles on my body that I didn't know I had - and I workout 4 days a week - while having fun. I recommend this place.  It is a little pricey, but if you have the money to invest, I highly recommend doing so.  You will have fun and meet great folks that are climbers.  Everyone roots each other on as we try to master the myriad climbing paths.  Have fun!!
Great bouldering gym! Clean, friendly, very chill. No poseurs in sight.

I came to Bridges with a small group of inexperienced climbers as part of their $6 Student Night on Friday. Toss in a $3 shoe rental and it came to $9 altogether for a great afternoon experience.When I got there around 5pm, it wasn't too crowded and there was plenty of space for us to climb. As a new climber though, it was a little confusing at first to figure out how everything worked from the difficulty rating system to how to get down after climbing up. Luckily there were plenty of helpful climbers around that were willing to answer my questions and give bits of advice. Bouldered and slacklined until my arms got tired.When we were leaving around 7:30-8pm, another large group of inexperienced people came in and took up a lot of the space. Unless you're a cheap college student, I would avoid Friday nights.Bridges also had cardio equipment and weight machines for a complete workout, in addition to a space for workout classes (Zumba, kickboxing, etc.).I'm a person that likes to workout, but not just stand around and lift weights, so I figure I'll be back before graduating.

Update: I still suck at bouldering but I genuinely enjoyed myself this visit! There was a good mix of levels of ability, the staff very sweet and I LOVE LOVE LOVE the Sauna! Just my luck that I try this place (which is around the corner from me) fall in love, and now I'm moving....damn!

Great bouldering gym.  I generally come in the middle of the day when it's relatively mellow.  The staff is very friendly and helpful and there's always lots of interesting and difficult problems (the routes at a given grade seem harder than other gyms I've climbed at).  The walls are pretty high and the top outs make the problems more difficult but more realistic to outside boudlering.  The are also much cheaper than other gyms in the area (i.e. touchstone) for memberships.  I do the slacklines occasionally between boulder problems.  Its a fun way to improve balance.  I don't use the exercise equipment much but there is a fair amount of that as well.

I went to Bridges recently after not climbing/bouldering for several months. The bouldering here is really top notch. I have never been to a better bouldering gym (ok, I have only been to 4 other places..). I went late in the evening, when I expect they see the largest crowds. There was still ample room and the gym did note feel too crowded. They have a wide variety of interesting problems. The padded floor is great, and is really quite necessary given that most of their problems top out quite high. The locker rooms are nice enough. The staff is more than pleasant. Do note go here if you are looking to lead or top-rope. There are a few ropes, but there is a reason no one was using them (all beginner routes, and quite short by roped standards). I don't slak-line, but it looks like a good place for that. The rest of the gym equipment seems fine (nothing special). They claim to have yoga classes, etc., but I don't know about those.

My partner and I *love* this gym. And that's saying a lot, considering I hate gyms and wasn't really a climber before we joined.  The facilities are immaculate.  The owners/staff are super friendly and always greet us by name.  Membership entitles you to all the free classes you want: yoga, core strengthening, climbing, slacklining, etc. The core class kicks my abs!I'd been gym climbing a few times before, and always with a belayer.  I've found that it's so nice to be able to just climb anything and not have to worry about that.

I had an excellent massage by Christina! I felt like i wasn't just being 'rubbed', this lady is a miracle worker/therapist! She was able to pinpoint areas on my back that i had forgotten i had injured 15 years ago. She worked them out and gave me helpful tips on how to keep these areas safe and healthy. I felt wonderful afterwards! Thank you and i will be back for more massages.

Went with as a group of five inexperienced climbers and had a great time.The staff was very helpful in giving us tips on both the bouldering wall and on the slack line. There were also plenty of easy routes, so everyone had a good place to start.

I haven't been working out for a while now and wanted to get back into shape so searched for some "decent" gyms in the area and the first one on my list was Bridges Rock.  The minute i walked in i knew this gym was awesome.  The staff is super friendly and welcomes everyone with a great smile.  Damien and his wife are totally cool.  They treat you like you're family.  He gave me a tour of the entire place.  I knew right away that i wanted to be a member.  So i joined.  Yesterday was my frist day there and it was incredible.  The tidyness and cleanliness of the gym is astonishing.  I've been to several gyms and this definately stands out.  They have free weights, treadmills, and some other machines you could use if you didn't want to rockclimb or slackline.  They have an incredible variety of classes from yoga, ab core workout to pilates spreadout over different times and days.  I tried rockclimbing for the very frist time and Damien was there to show me some basic steps and guide me.  He's been an incredible help.  I won't lie and say it was easy and fun, it was HARD and definately fun but i am seriously going back for more.  He said "it's like a language, you'll eventually get better with practice."  The gym isn't too crowded.  You can get in, get your workout and leave.  It's definately NOT a meatmarket or a social ground.  People come to work out and have fun while doing so.  It's in a great location and the staff and members are friendly and welcoming.  Try it if you haven't.

It is a bit small, but the coupon they offer is worth it to go.  I am not sure if the other indoor rock climbing gyms that they are affiliated with are the same size.  My daughter, niece, my friend and her son enjoyed it. There are many other things to utilize while you are at the facility.
Went here for a free event, let's just say rock climbing isn't for me. But it was clean, fun (while it lasted), and a great rock climbing gym.

Went yesterday for a massage - Justin (I believe) was great - he hit every spot that needed to be worked on - wish I would of purchased a longer massage- I have been before and Kristina was fabulous also. I will be back ;)

I've only visited one other rockclimbing gym in the area (Ironworks), and I have to say that this place is so much more inviting.  It's not as popular I imagine because of the location and the concentration on bouldering, but that suits me just fine.  No lines, no crowds, you can just take everything at your own pace.  Love it.The pricing's really good too.  You can spend a small fortune dropping in at Ironworks, but at Bridges everything's pretty reasonable.Little side benefit: once you're done climbing, you can grab some food or boba tea at 99 Ranch next door!

an indoor bouldering gym.got there almost right after opening so the entire facility was my clam.i feel bad that i forgot the lone worker's name cause he was real laid back and helpful.bouldering is a different experience than rock climbing; i was worn out after an hour.this review is weird.

Really nice place for bouldering, much better than Ironworks for this purpose. Great atmosphere, and also cheaper. It would be nice if the opening hours would be extended, 7pm on weekends is a bit too early, though I appreciate the workers also need the rest...

Lately, the past few sets aren't fun but weird.Padding was pretty awesome when it was new and fresh but it has become a nuisance.  No one likes to trip everywhere they walk or twist their ankle by having their feet sink in a torn pad.  Fix it or replace it.No air circulation, gets way too hot and stuffy.It feels like there isn't any maintenance here.This place was awesome, now it's just eh.Also, I know many of the parents who bring their kids have complained about this but the front desk has obviously ignored them: Don't blast obscene gangster rap during children's birthday parties.

Came here a while ago when there was a Yelp/Groupon deal. I think it was $15 for 3 visits? This included free shoe rentals. I liked how you could use one of the 3 visits to bring a friend.  This place was so much fun! People are so helpful and I enjoyed attempting to be agile and fit. Lol it's a lot harder than it looks and requires more upper body strength than I thought. It's a great physical and mental (it's kind of like a puzzle) workout. This place also offers treadmills, some free weights, tight lining, and yoga. If I had more time, I'd pick up bouldering as a hobby and become a member at Bridges.

I LOVE this gym! Not only is the staff amazingly friendly and chill, but they ALL are extremely knowledgeable about bouldering and slack-lining (what the gym specializes in), and the whole staff actually DOES the bouldering and slack-lining! Which I know at a lot of gyms, the staff knows how to sell the gym but it's not always the case to find that they actually work out at the facility. Although they specialize in bouldering and slack-lining, they offer a wide variety of classes to take from yoga to zumba, and they also have a full gym with tons of brand new weight machines, free weights, physio balls, foam rollers...basically everything you need! The locker rooms have showers, a sauna, and are always spotlessly clean and well maintained. It's nice that during the week they are open until 10 PM, and they are open until 7 PM on the weekends I believe. Another great thing is that they offer student discounts on memberships and everything, and they have a minimum 4 month contract which is a great thing to offer in comparison to a year or 2 year contract. My favorite thing of all is that they do have good business for being a little hidden, but it's not crowded at all and I don't feel overwhelmed there like I do at most gyms.If you are looking to try a new approach to working out, or want to try something new and fun, you have to check out Bridges!! You won't be dissappointed. It truely is a hidden find!! :)

The very idea of Bridges is exciting and new to the concept of indoor rock climbing gym model. Bridges is unique b/c as far as I know, it's the only gym of it's kind to exist. They have extensive slackline setups from short, beginner lines, long loose lines, to high lines above the boulder problems. This is great b/c rarely do indoor climbing gyms even have a slackline, if they do it's set up inconveniently and die-hard lead climbing jocks always complain if it's in their way. At Bridges the slack lining has equal importance as do climbing.The layout is utilized well. You have a cafe upstairs, and at the ground level there's bouldering problems, and slacklines galore.The bouldering is unique to where you can actually top out and then walk down to the ground.Overall I think this is such a new and fun idea/twist to the indoor climbing gyms that it's bound to pick up and become popular for everyone!

If you're into bouldering, this is THE gym for you.  No matter your style... vertical & crimpy? check. slabby & technical? check. highball topouts? how does rolling over 18+ feet off the ground sound to you? how about their huge 30 foot cave?  one word, SICK!  I've climbed at most of the gyms in the bay area, and have been a member of Touchstone for about 2 years... and mean no offense to any of them when I say that this place is an experience unlike no other in the bay area.Based on my first day there, the difficulty of the problems seem to be firm but fair, with a very nice variety for all styles and levels of climbing.  A very nice alternative to the Touchstone & PG mega-gyms, Bridges will have me coming back on a very regular basis.I didn't check out the fitness equipment or the cafe upstairs, as I was overwhelmed by the climbing options.  Location is easy go get to, right behind the Ranch 99 complex in El Cerrito.  Welcome to the neighborhood Bridges, I wish you much success.

Best & cheapest climbing gym for bouldering / slacklining in the Bay Area. Amazing rates, great membership deals seasonally. Holds are beautiful, clean. Routes are well-marked, of varying difficulty for all levels. Great atmosphere. Wish they had one in SF!Friday night is college night, and it's packed during the school year. Go or avoid at your preference.

Bridges rocks my world. First off, the bouldering problems and atmosphere is by far superior to Ironworks. I'm a boulderer at heart, so if no-ropes is not your thing, than this is not your place. You can top-out on all problems and the range of problems is staggering, considering the relatively small size of the place (again, compared to Ironworks). Prices are decent, especially before the afternoon rate kicks in, and when my brother and I go around 8 a.m., we are very often alone, or climbing among a few, sleepy-eyed, mellow fellows. The slacklining area is great and is a great way to rest your hands and arms between big climbs, while continuing to engage your core and balancing ability. I've never had to wait to get on a machine (elliptical/bike, etc), and enjoy the sauna after every climb. AND the staff is always super friendly, even at 8 on a winter's morning.Highly recommend.

Thank you Bridges for being my awesome, affordable, local gym.  The owner and staff are all lovely.  It's kind of a sweet, all ages establishment.  And while I'm not a climber, I can use the eliptical trainer to my heart's content (boring, but effective!), I'm slooowly learning how to slackline, and I have access to a regular schedule of great yoga classes all for the very reasonable monthly membership fee.  Yay.  Thank you Bridges!!!  I'm a fan!

I love the selection of classes---from all kinds of yoga to Zumba.  The yoga studio is in a separate building from the gym, so it's not very loud in there.  The staff is super low-key and friendly.  I love that there's permanent slacklining, and the lines periodically change in height and width.  The bouldering space is pretty big and doesn't feel crowded like other gyms in the area....reminds me a lot of my old bouldering gym in Portland- The Circuit!

This place is AWESOME!  If I lived nearby, I would totally get a membership here, whatever it cost.The rock climbing is fun, there's lots of space and different levels of difficulty, including a spot which is basically hanging upside down (no thanks!).  I had a lot of fun climbing the rocks, and I love how it's so open so you can just go on your own and have fun.  They have a big open climbing area, another area off to the side with ropes if you want to be harnessed in, a smaller place for young children to climb, and they have slack-lines set up so you can work on your balance, too.What is awesome about this place is that upstairs they also have treadmills, elliptical machines, and exercise bikes!  Downstairs, they have a whole room full of lifting machines!  So you really can go here for everyday workouts, cardio, weight training, along with some really fun rock climbing.They also have really good hours, and the staff is very helpful if you need them, and out of your face if you don't.Oh, yea, I almost forgot!  The bathroom has showers and a SAUNA!  Just awesome.I've never seen a place with so much stuff in one location like this.  Definitely check it out!

Wow..I want to give this 5 but I cant...cause of the ropes from when I did the harnessed rockclimbing. The guy gave us a great run through, but they kept getting stuck..and it really freaked me out. This place has an AMAZING bathroom, sauna, cafe, everything...i love this place...but the fact that the rope kept getting stuck.
Bouldering-oriented gym like the one I grew up in. They always seem to have new problems (bouldering routes) set up.
Awesome place.  Tons of intermediate level walls to get better quick on.

This isn't really a rock climbing gym ... this is more like a bouldering gym . There's only about 6-7 paths for rock climbing with the ropes and all the . The rest of the place is filled with bouldering which is basically the same thing but without ropes . Bouldering isn't as easy as it looks . Bouldering is actually kind of hard . My hands got tired and gave out very quickly . I can't really compare bouldering to rock climbing because I've never done rock climbing before . It's really cool how you can exit from the top for the bouldering paths . Just be careful of your head and be sure to duck down a bit when you get to the top because the ceilings are kinda low . If you don't duck down , you will hit your head on the ceiling . The exit route is narrow so be careful and don't get in people's way . There is a mini path on the sides where you can climb down from and exit . In addition to rock climbing and bouldering , they also have slacklining which is basically walking across tight nylon ropes tied against something . It's actually pretty hard to walk across the tight nylon ropes while maintaining your balance and not shaking . It's cool how they have ropes hanging from the ceiling for you to hold onto and guide you across the nylon ropes . They have three kinds of nylon ropes . There's one that's thinner and one that's thicker . There's also one that's very high . It was kinda cool watching one of the staff members jumping and doing tricks on the high slackline . There's workout machines at this gym as well . There's weight machines near the entrance and cardio machines and free weights upstairs . There's also sofas , chairs , tables , and board games upstairs . There's a massage place but I haven't checked it out yet . I heard there is a locker room and sauna too but I haven't checked it out as well . The front of the gym is kind of weird ... it looks like this gym was previously a garage or warehouse that's been converted into a gym . The parking lot is very small and only has a few parking spaces . This gym offers classes like yoga and other stuff which is pretty cool . I will be back for bouldering and to check out some of their classes . This gym is located behind Ranch 99 . I've been to Ranch 99 a million times but I never noticed this gym until I looked up " rock climbing " on Yelp . This is one of the reasons why I love Yelp . I discover all these places I wouldn't otherwise notice or know about . This is a decent gym if you're in the area but otherwise , I wouldn't recommend going out of your way to come here unless you love bouldering . If you plan on visiting , check out the deal on Yelp ... it's pretty good . You get 3 day passes to the gym for $25 and if you decide to get a membership at the gym , you can get your activation fee waived . Btw , their shoes might feel very small and cramped . It might feel weird but that's how it's supposed to be ... your toes are supposed to curl a bit . It doesn't feel weird at all when you're bouldering .
No toprope, but toprope is for sissies anyway.  Cheap, and right next to ranch 99 so you can go get your groceries after.
