Bridges is awesome. The bouldering is really cool - we aren't outside climbers (or real climbers, one might say) so we can't really evaluate the awesomeness. When I scramble up and over a V0, when I've conquered that mental game of courage and shaking forearms, it pure euphoria. That's all icing for me though. Really I go there for a monthly rate on decent yoga. The only thing is, the yoga isn't merely decent anymore. They bring their interesting personalities and incorporate bits of their own practices, which is what all the best instructors anywhere do. You can psyche yourself into thinking that you should be able to do that crazy feet-in-the-air crow pose with back arched without crashing into the ground. You can over exert yourself into weeping into the couch for two weeks. The teachers at Bridges are smart and caring, and can quickly find and help the beginners to learn how to self modify and care for themselves. Bridges is awesome. The wee workout center upstairs seems small, but it's never been overcrowded. If you know how to lift weights, then it has everything you need except for good options for doing pull ups. That's what the huge amount of bouldering and rock climbing walls are for. Climb a wall or eight, and your back is strong. Then head upstairs to do some curls and sit-ups, etc. and you have a pretty amazing workout.\ Never too crowded, best clientele you could ever ask for at a gym, totally clean and cozy, cheap, Bridges is everything you could want.

awesome bouldering. nice employees. technique classes. yoga included in the membership.has some cardio machines, weights, bands, kettlebells, foamrollers for the traditional work out. often have deals on memberships and initiation fees.

Why would anyone get a regular gym membership? Bridges has all you need from a gym (weights, exercise machines, classes), but that is tremendously dull. This gym is all about the boulders. Scary huge top out boulders, steep overhanging roof climbs, and a bunch of really fun problems. They set regularly and the staff is friendly and helpful. Ropes are lame; climb at Bridges!

pros:- tons of bouldering- nice open space- clean locker rooms and sauna- friendly staff- friendly patrons- good music- constant new routescons: - too far from where i live after moving away from el cerrito

Man I LOVE this place!!! I had never done bouldering or rock climbing & they made me feel so comfortable & showed me exactly how to do what. We had a phenomenal instructor named Wendy who was so passionate about climbing and explained all the details and techniques in such an awesome way that inspired me to climb everything the other people who had previous experience did. And when you fall there is so much padding that you can't feel a thing. I highly recommend this place for first timers or even experienced climbers, very clean, staff was so friendly and the lessons are very reasonably priced.

I love bridges! I dislocated my ankle attempting a huge dyno there, and still I return for more!Located about a 10 min walk, and 2 min bike ride from El Cerrito plaza Bart station, bridges boasts the largest bouldering walls, and over hang space in the bay. The extent of the climbing problems presented is unmatched. If you want to get good at climbing you climb here. The allowance of topping out adds a satisfactory bonus to conquering your desired route. 3 slack line set ups from beginner to advanced are a great way to improve body equilibrium, also an upstairs weight set and treadmills are available for core workout needs. Saunas are available in locker rooms.The cafe and lounge area is great for winding down after working out, with free Wi-fi, and organic food. The always more than helpful staff is available for any inquiry, or if you just want to chop it up while smearing face. They offer drop in climbing lessons as well as drop in yoga. Child care is available. Parking is very limited; however the mall parking lot is not too far away.
Brightest, friendliest bouldering in the Bay. Would (and do) strongly recommend it all of my friends, regardless of their previous climbing experience.

I've only come here for bouldering, but I plan on joining up and trying out a few classes. For bouldering, it's a great, low-key space. The $6 for students on Friday is a good deal, but be forewarned -- it's packed nearly all the way until closing time! Crowd is friendly, non-competitive, and folks are willing to throw out some handy tips when you're stuck, or strike up a friendly conversation.
Been here a couple of times. Facility is decent. Climbers here are cool.

If you enjoy bouldering, Bridges will be utter heaven for you.  This is the nicest bouldering gym I've ever seen.The facilities are incredible.  The walls are about 18' tall, which is about 5' higher than the walls at the Touchstone family of gyms -- Mission Cliffs, Ironworks, Western Power Company, etc.  Climbers are supposed to "top out" on each of the climbs.  So, rather than having to jump down 18' when you finish a problem, you are supposed to pull yourself up and over the wall to a small walkway that you follow back down to the floor.  It's much more like climbing outside.  It makes the climbs a little harder, but it also reduces the risk of injury from jumping down.The floors are comprised of nearly 3' thick padding everywhere, so you don't have to drag mats around when you want to get on a challenging problem.  The gym is spacious as well.  So if you want to sit in front of a problem for a while and think about it, nobody is going to land on you while you're spaced out.One of the route setters I spoke to said they had 140 climbs up.  And the climbs are *fun*.  They tend to be set a little harder than the bouldering problems at the Touchstone gyms, but they are probably closer to the difficulty level of outdoor problems.  The staff said they plan to swap out climbs about every five weeks, which is more frequent than the Touchstone gyms seem to change their problems (closer to six or eight weeks).  There have been times where I've done pretty much every climb that I can do at my level at all three Bay Area Touchstone gyms and I still had to wait a couple weeks before new problems appeared.There will be a vegetarian cafe opening up in the gym shortly.  They have three slack lines for folks that are into that.  They have a small section of climbs for belaying, but they seem more targeted to kids.  The locker rooms are nice and have saunas. They don't have any weight lifting equipment, but they do have some treadmills and elipticals.  The *only* negative about the place is that it would be tougher to climb there alone.  An 18' fall without a spotter is kind of dangerous, even with the ample padding.  Climbers tend to be pretty supportive of each other, so I doubt that will be much of an issue once attendance ramps up a bit.All of the staff members I've talked to were super cool.  If bouldering is your thing and you're already a Touchstone member, I'd be surprised if you don't find yourself with another climbing gym membership.  I wish I could give this place six stars.

Great place to take kids!  This is one of my daughter's favorite places to go.  She's 9.  The staff was super helpful getting her set-up and giving her a few pointers, as well as giving me tips in how to best support her.  There is such a huge range that she was quickly able to find places on the climbing wall where she could feel successful.  When she gets tired of climbing, she heads to the tightrope.  We also LOVE the cafe upstairs.  Super delicious, organic,  homemade-style cooking.
Great value when your coming in before 3pm. Nice staff and atmosphere. Definitely the place to go if you want to start bouldering.

$100 for the whole summer (3 months) and they even waved the initiation fee. Not sure if they are still offering this deal. This gym rocks! One price for almost EVERYTHING including yoga and something called Qigong. Check out their website for more detailed info. Excellent locker room facilities. Hot yoga instructor by the way. Bonus. I think they have a different instructor on different days though. I can't remember which day I went. I usually just do the bouldering. It's hardly ever crowded when I go in the evenings. Yoga fills up fast so you might want to get there a few minutes early to get a spot on the floor.

Dropped in .. amazing location, unexpected actually.   I always have been an avid rock climber.  From top roping, lead climbing, self belay, ice climbing, technical climbing, speed climbing, safety belay, bouldering and even free climbing, I actually own lots of the coolest gear.  My experience in rock climbing goes back long before rock climbing gyms, so it is nice for me to see this turn into a extreme sport.  Rockclimbing is a lot like playing chess, with more than just trying to ascend to the top, you get points on style, difficulty, prior knowledge of how one positions themself.  Bridges Rock Gym is a safe, new environment specific to "bouldering".   Like several natural locations throughout the bay area, Cragmont, Indian Rock, Mickey Beach, Turtle Rock... parts or portions of a difficult solution to rockclimbing is rarely higher than 10 or so feet off the ground. Granted one could hurt themselves if falling wrong, generally the hopes is you would crash on a provided softened pad first. Bouldering can be a lot harder than roped routes as Bridges Rock Gym will prove to you.  Certainly drop over..  Cost is $58 monthly and/or $15 day pass which includes Yoga for free.  There is a nice cafe, showers, sauna and free wi-fi.

This place is kind of unorganized but the pilates classes with Emily are great!  I've taken a lot of pilates classes and she is by far the best instructor.  She's very easy to understand, comes around and corrects and/or makes modifications to your position, despite the class size being too large sometimes, and she's always cheerful.  I highly recommend her class, though now it might be more even more full.

Came here with my cousins and we had a good time. I didn't really know what I was getting myself into, and even though I could have worked on more walls, I still had a lot of fun. It's not a place for harness climbing, as this place is really small. But boulder climbing is a really good workout and a way to get your adrenaline going a little bit. I would really like to get into this, because I think it's a great way to stay in shape, get over a fear of heights, and build confidence. And how convenient that it is near Ranch 99.
There's plenty to do for the beginner and the expert! Great value when you buy the Yelp deal!
Best bouldering gym I've been to by far. Tons of different routes for any degree of difficulty and for a great price!

I am very new to rock climbing as a sport. I've always loved scrambling on rocks and climbing trees as a kid (and sometimes as an adult) and it's good to see that it never left my system. I came here on opening weekend and was instantly hooked. It's easy enough for a n00b like me, yet still be a challenge as I gain strength and experience. The facilities are clean and well kept. They are adding fitness machines up stairs and I intend to take advantage of the yoga classes this week, so I can't yet offer a review on them yet. My hands and nails are shot and I accumulate scrapes and bruises but I don't care. It's worth it. I feel like a big kid on a playground again blissfully unaware that I am actually getting a great workout.
My favorite Gym! I love taking Zumba here.

I've known of this little climbing gym pretty much since it opened as it is right next to the Ranch 99 mall.  Though no longer a resident of the East Bay, I had never gotten a chance to check it out.  I recently was in Richmond for a week and purchased a groupon for a 3 day pass.  The parking lot needs some work (I hate driving on gravely parking lots, I'm always scared one of my tires will get popped).  Also, parking is rather limited.  The bouldering section of the gym is great.  So many problems to try.  I'm a weakling and try to stick to V0 and V1 routes.  There were LOTS to try.  The locker rooms arealso  really nice and the staff was very friendly and helpful.  However the regular gym section was not the best.  (I know I know, it's not the priority of the gym, i get it).  I liked that it has a nice view of people bouldering from the treadmills.  The weights were pretty limited though.  I definitely ended up improvising quite a bit to try and keep up with my usual workout routine.  But overall, this is a nice little bouldering gym.

Friendly, easily accessible rock gym. Doesn't have bells and whistles, but who cares..it has what you need and the people are cool. Lots of classes and no very crowded climbing, except weekends. love it here.

I decided to try this gym because is very close to my work, and wanted to try pilates before staring my work day.  The class was all right.  It is great for stretching, but not for cardio.  The showers in the bathroom have no doors, and they are not clean.  The drain in the shower is a bit slow.  I did try rock climbing here for the first time.  That was challenging, and I still need to work on my nerves when I get to the top. :P

We had a great time at bridges the staff was extremely nice and helpful  the yelp deal is totally worth it , I'm excited to try one of many classes they have for yoga,bouldering,ect. Also one thing that made it awesome was the music they played , I could boulder to Hendrix and Marley all day ! Thanks Bridges , you rock! Haha

I went here last Sunday with my friend who has been rock-climbing for awhile now. My friend got this bring-a-guest free for once a month and he dragged me along.Upon entering the premises, I was like whoa this place looks pretty cool. I heard that this place had just opened at the beginning of the year, (2009).As I'm a complete newbie in rock-climbing, this place is pretty awesome for me. The place still has that "newly constructed" smell so that was a plus for me since I like new stuffs.  The biggest plus was the locker room. Holy crap, this is way better than most gyms I've been to, especially compared to City Beach in Fremont.  The locker room is not exactly huge but it is really clean and well maintained.  There's a separate sauna room, shower stalls, mix of small and large lockers, urinals and toilets. Each has its own area and yet blends all together I think that's a clever area design. The upstairs portion houses the cafe area, which I regretfully did not try, but I managed to use the treadmills right beside that area. My friend and I just used it to warm ourselves up before doing any sort of climbing. It was kind of chilly when we got inside at first but was gone just a few minutes of threadmill jog.As for the boulders, I believe are all 20 feet high or so so there are no required harness to climb the walls. However, once ya get to the top, it's still quite scary (for me) and there still risk of attaining injury if you fall down from the top. I fell down once when I missed a handhold and I landed completely on my feet straight down on the mats. My knees did not like that at all. Since I'm not familiar on the climbing grading, I rather not critic that area.During my stay there, a group of kids came in together with a couple of the staffs. Man, some of the kids are being bratty but I applaud the staffs' well-meanings in teaching the kids, and their patience. At the end of our stay, I came out feeling sore on the hands but beaming from the fun. The girl, forgive me I forgot her name, behind the counter was really helpful, answering my friend's questions. Price-wise, I can only stipulate that it's competitively-priced from the other gyms.  But one of the pluses that they offered is a 10-visit punch card. No expiration and you can come whenever.Overall, a very satisfying experience. If only they weren't so far from my house, I would go 3 times a week.

Updated 4: 11/2014: Happy to report that they are finally paying more attention to many of the issues noted below, though I often have to be the one to let them know it needs to be fixed.  The folks who work here are very nice, and I'm very glad that I can improve my rating in accordance with the improved service. That said, the gym is quite crowded now - congrats on rising membership, but maybe time to find  a less crowded facility...Updated 3 (7/2013): After nearly three years here, my conclusion is that this is a climbing gym with a lot of potential that is not particularly well managed.  The staff, while generally nice (though one new staff member has much to learn about customer service) is not very motivated to respond to customer complaints (again, with a couple of exceptions).  For example:1. The soap dispensers in the showers are still almost always empty.  I can mention it days if not weeks in a row and NOTHING changes.  If you come here and need to leave clean (e.g., if you are going to work or a meeting after you work out), bring your own soap.  2. The Pilates balls are almost always under inflated.  After mentioning it for about a month, maybe they will get inflated. Sometimes it takes 2-3 months.3. The fan near the elliptical machines is invariably so caked with dust it might as well be called a "dust mite dispenser" -- it is truly gross.  When somebody accidentally knocks it over, it emits a dust cloud that spreads for a good 20 feet in all directions.  I always make sure to turn it AWAY from me when I am working out.4. The sauna is broken in some way about half the time, which would not be the case if they posted the sign with the language that I recommended 2 years ago to tell members not to douse the coals with water, which fries the coils.5.  They also need some kind of protocol for what kind of behavior is acceptable versus nauseating in the sauna. For example, there is the guy who stands there naked with sweat dripping from his, um you know, creating a big disgusting puddle of genital sweat on the wooden bench.  There are others who leave the sauna soaked with sweat and water and the coils shorted out, so you have to reset the unit.  Some seriously strange behavior...6.  The toilet stalls are frequently out of toilet paper7.  I tried their massage program, but after two cancellations in a row (one of which I wasn't told about until I arrived), I moved on. 7/13/2013: my wife's massage was just cancelled last minute b/c therapist was "sick" (right...we are guessing "hung over" is more accurate). Unbelievable - again?! Really?!In conclusion, the ownership needs to hire somebody as a manager who holds staff accountable for taking care of the facilities and maintaining the equipment.  If they did, Bridges could quickly rise to 4 or even 5 stars. But given some recent bad experiences, it is back down to 2.Update 2: the owner has finally fixed the squeaking elliptical machine and the soap dispensers in the shower have not been empty at all this week (for the first time in ages).  As I noted, he's a very nice guy and as promised, I've updated my rating again to reflect the improvements.  Thanks!Update: just a day after posting the below review, the gym finally added more pilates balls (including a large one) and finally inflated the third one.  For that, I'll add another star.  Original review This gym has a ton of potential -- if you're a rock climber it gets a better rating.If you want a place to use exercise equipment like I do, it gets only two stars because they don't take care of their equipment and the staff is non-responsive to requests to take care of problems with it.  There doesn't seem to be a sense of "I'm taking care of this gym so our customers are happy" type responsibility among the staff.For example:- their showers are almost always out of soap.  Very annoying after a workout.  I've told them probably 20 times, and still almost every time I use the showers, the soap is empty in at least 2 of their 3 shower stalls.  The attendant on duty could perhaps check the soap every hour or two so this doesn't happen.  Instead when I look down from the elliptical machine, the attendant is typically surfing the web. - they have not inflated their pilates ball since I joined in September, and I've requested it no less than five times. Come on.- the owner (a very nice guy) told me he was going to get some larger pilates balls.  I told him that I had a doctor's order to use a larger one as part of my rehab exercises, and he said he'd get one.  That was three months ago. What happened??- the elliptical machine I use squeaks annoyingly I hope they can get it together and start paying more attention to their equipment and customers, as the gym has a ton of potential!  And the staff are MUCH nicer than many of the staff at Iron Works.  But right now, it's definitely not a place I'm excitedly telling my local friends about.

This place is awesome!  I am not a rock climber but I found it to be way more fun to work out there verses a regular gym.  The slack lines are super fun and there is a nice sauna in the ladies room.  The staff are friendly and approachable.  They also have the best prices around for yoga ($10 a class).

This is a basically A Clean Well-Lighted Place For Bouldering.  The owner/founders are super friendly, and this is a family affair among two sisters and a husband.  You'll find wall-to-wall heavy padding under rather high bouldering problems.  A sauna, a few machines, yoga space, and a kiddie care room.  They do birthday parties well.  You can walk from El Cerrito Plaza BART.  Everything to like.  Note: the place is bouldering and slacklining focused, no mini-El Capitan's here, and very limited top-roping.

i don't top rope, i only boulder, so i was really excited when i heard about this place. i went a few times but i couldn't get down with the culture of this gym. maybe it's that the climbers seem a bit on the younger side and so they aren't thinking about the possibility of getting injured or are just generally more oblivious. all the times i've gone here i had to be really extra vigilant about people wandering around directly below me while i'm on the wall, constantly afraid that if i fell i would hurt them and/or myself. i haven't had this concern at the touchstone gyms, where my experience has been that people hang back until it seems like it's their turn to approach the wall or just ask. also, i described that i was having a problem with the gym equipment and the people working at the desk didn't offer to help me figure it out, which i thought was rude.

I love this place.  I use it not for rock climbing but as a gym and for yoga classes.  Want to give a special recommendation for Yoga teachers Vlad (tues and thurs 4:30 to 5:30)  and Tosha (fri 12 to 1).

So I called Bridges with an issue I had concerning some vouchers that I wanted to redeem. They were SUPER accommodating and helpful without any hesitation. It was amazing. Excellent service. Far above and beyond what I had expected or even hoped for (I had never been there before so I didn't know what to expect). I cannot thank them enough!

Pleasant community feeling. I come for the Pilates classes. Some of the teachers are better than others, but all are basically solid.  Staffed by nice, conscientious kids. Fairly clean locker room, showers and sauna.

I held my 9 yo son's b-day party here.  He was ambivalent about it beforehand, but after its success, he announced, "That was my coolest birthday party ever!"  That's saying quite a lot.  Damien's wife was very pleasant, helpful and made sure all the kids had a good time, inc. my self-conscious 11 yo daughter.  They have a cafe/party area upstairs which is clean and inviting.  Bridges Rock Gym is a great example why we should support local, small businesses.

Fun! I started by doing yoga here.  They have lots of classes at different levels.  Then I started to use their gym.  Its a small area but you get to work out and watch people climb, pretty cool!  Staff was always very pleasant.
Great staff- they go out of your way to make you feel comfortable and to give you advice. We had so much fun here, and will definitely be back!

awesome bouldering routes, friendly staff, plenty of space, adequate gym, and a space for yoga/workouts (that i never had a chance to try). and of course, slack lining! it's a great deal for an all around workout space.

Facility clean, staff friendly, yoga instructors GREAT, especially Lynn, her class is very challenging. Pilates instructor GREAT! They are a relatively new gym so I see them continuing to improve themselves (like adding insulation to the yoga shed, etc..). The great monthly fee is what attracted me and they have preformed as well as a high priced gym. I love this place and highly recommend it!
awesome gym with tons of good bouldering routes that you can top out on, weight and cardio equipment, frequent good-quality cardio and yoga sessions, and even slacklines!

I love this gym!  I've always enjoyed bouldering more than rock climbing and this is everything I want and more.   All you need are some climbing shoes, chalk and chalk bag and you're good to go.  You don't need to find a climbing partner, put a harness on or rope yourself in... etc.  Plus, the gym is very well padded so you don't have to drag some dinky crash pad underneath your climbing all.  They also have classes such as yoga, pilates and abs, if you want a change of pace.
great overall gym, offers a variety of workouts
